description:
$5 beers?! That is unheard of in the city. 

My friend and I were very lucky to stumble across this place one night. We were supposed to go to the museum but tickets sold out and we wanted to figure out something to do while we waited for our friends who did get in. 

We talked to the security there and she mentioned to visit the little shamrock. Just half a mile away from the museum. This security guard is also a bartender at this spot. I wish I could remember her name! Very friendly lady she is. 

$5 beers, is a bargain in the city especially since I'm not from there. We went around 7 pm and it  as quiet and plenty of available seating on nice furniture, couches, chairs. They have table games available. 

I like that the bartender would come up to us and ask if we wanted drinks instead of having to go up to the bar. Next time I'm in town I'm coming back for good priced quality beer.
author: Ami S.

description:
This is a no frills bar with lots of character. Cash only is their motto. The woman behind the bar was attentive and friendly. She handles the entire place. Eager beer drinkers line up at the bar for their favorites brews. They offered lots of IPA on tap along with the standards.

There are tables with games and the place was full of people who just seemed to call this place home.

I was amazing at the old fashioned cash register. I didn't get a photo but I did snap a quick photo of the Fireball machine.
author: Dave U.

description:
I love this neighborhood bar, and have for many years. Great mix of genuine folks from the neighborhood with a few tourists who "get" the vibe. Bob is an exceptionally talented and attentive bartender. I've witnessed her handling unruly patrons with a level of grace and composure that I myself could not command. Even after being slapped in the face, she kept her cool, removed the offender without further escalation, and returned calmly and coolly to her business. 

Cozy, welcoming, and reasonably priced drinks.
author: Garrett H.

description: Amazing bar with a lot of history in every corner. Cheap and delicious beer compare to everything else in San Francisco. Lots of board games!
author: Maria Paz I.

description:
We came solely for the fireplace. 
It was crowded on a this past Friday night and not my vibe.

Nothing bad just not for me. We got our drinks fast.

Not many spots available to be situated inside.  
We did get to be next to the fireplace though.

I didn't think it was super loud or anything.
But, I thought it was too loud to be reading at the bar 
which I did spot, someone, doing: to each their own.

They didn't have Hornitos so I was stuck with Cazadores, 
and I didn't like it at all. 

We all left after I finished my drink.
author: Lilian L.

description:
Perfectly chilled drinks. When you get a drink in a big ice cold glass it can taste completely different (and a thousand times better than) from a bottle. Came in and realized as I went to post this that they weren't technically open yet (1 pm, yelp days they open at 2) but the bartender was perfectly friendly and quick. There's also a very cute small dog here that hasn't barked at all so what more could you ask for?

Cash only! ATM in the back
author: Aryana W.

description:
Looking for love in all the wrong places.

No, seriously, I am.  So, I've thrown myself into dating and, oh boy, am I too old for this!   I met my date on a Monday night here.  It was quiet on the night I went with the bar less than half full.  The bartender seemed very nice and friendly.  The drinks were cheap ($12 total for wine and a diet coke with well vodka) but my drink had no kick.   Nice ambiance and, again, nice bartender.  She hollered out goodnight to us as we left.  Nice touch.
author: Linda H.

description: We got Irish coffees, very good! And went there in the afternoon to play chess (which they have there). Right next to Golden Gate Park which is nice!
author: Rachel C.

description: This is an amazing cash only, warm and friendly bar near my work. They do the best Irish Coffees and even a sassy hot toddy if you are losing your voice, like I was, due to an annoying cough.
author: Tracy A.

description: The Little Shamrock is a fun little dive bar in the Inner Sunset, right on the edge of Golden Gate Park. We were walking around the botanical gardens and wanted to find a fun place to play some games, have a conversation, get some cheap drinks, and watch the game. We got all of that here. They also have a big section to throw darts in the back, which is always a fun activity! If you are looking for a laid back dive bar in the area, this is the place to come to!
author: Ross S.

description:
My FAVORITE Sunset bar. Attracts a really solid crowd of people (mostly locals and industry folk)-- good for reading a book and/or socializing. I've met so many wonderful people here-- games, books everywhere, and a dartroom in the back where you can plug in your OWN iPhone to play your music! It's like walking into your best friend's living room... 

If that wasn't enough, they ALSO let you bring in your own food! You can grab burritos at Gordos and cheap beers here-- and have a fabulous evening.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Big fan of the Little Shamrock!

Definitely a neighborhood vibe, dog friendly, grab a pitcher of beer and play some board games! 

On a Saturday night it was busy but not at all crowded. There was plenty of space for people to leisurely hang out or play a game of choice (they've got 2 Backgammon tables and many more game options).

CASH ONLY is important to note.
author: Rachel R.

description:
CASH ONLY

It's old alright.  You walk in and can feel the history seeping from the walls.  Beers were cold and cheap.  My kinda place.  Definitely a dive atmosphere but they have books and games.  Cool place to grab a drink and lounge on their antique couches for a few. 

Service was friendly and attentive.
author: Candace R.

description:
How could you not love this place? It's cozy with mismatched furniture, boardgames and books everywhere, friendly bartenders, and the game is always on. Plus you can't beat seeing Coconut curled up by the fire. 

As everyone else has said, just remember to bring cash!
author: April H.

description: Cool place, decent prices. Music is not too loud, and there's board games and books. Happy hour is $1 off well drinks. 2 dart boards in the back room.
author: George M.

description:
Anxious to stop by for a drink since I am a fan of John Lescroart's mystery novels which are centered in SF. The Little Shamrock is frequented by many of the fictitious characters in his books. This place is just as described in Lescroart's books. No frills, serious drinks, friendly bartenders,  local crowd and, has been around for 120 years!
Will definitely return when doing something in Golden Gate Park. Right on the edge of the park.
author: Joe M.

description: I remember hanging out here, playing games with friends and really enjoying my time here. They have a good atmosphere and space and was just really welcoming and fun.
author: Oliver G.

description: I love this small neighborhood pub. It feels like a home away from home. Tons of friendly people flock here,.The bar tenders are friendly and the ambience cozy. Bonus is the dart room in back.
author: Kirsten F.

description: Hidden gem next to the botanical gardens. I always enjoy a good Irish dive bar and The Little Shamrock doesn't disappoint.  Friendly staff, diverse patrons, and eclectic old furniture all add to the experience.
author: Tim T.

description: Wow, such a great experience, from the warm drinks to the cold women, it was an absolute blast. I must say the bartender Bob is by far the most beautiful, kind woman I've had the pleasure of meeting. If I could come in for all of her shifts, I would probably broke, but in love. Definitely coming back here again, just watch out for that dog watermelon, she can be vicious!
author: Chad B.

description: Long live The Shamrock. Great vibes, great drinks, and great bartenders. Definitely an institution in SF that should live on forever.
author: Mark C.

description:
I love a good dive bar and The Little Shamrock is just that. 

Cash only
Simple drinks
Couches
Board games

But best of all Darts - the dart boards have their own little room in back - with its own sound system that you can plug your phone into and play your own music.
author: Shannon H.

description:
This pub is great!
The drinks were poured heavily (how I love it) and the place was nice and dark during a hot sunny day.
My friend & I played a fun game of backgammon while enjoying drinks.
One star was taken away because it is a cash only bar and the closest atm machine is in what my friends named "rape alley." It was a creepy place to access money.
author: Tracy P.

description:
Great place to hang out! 
There's four televisions, boardgames, and dart boards in the back.
author: Karen L.

description:
Little Shamrock and I, we've got a good thing going.

Yes, the place has a bit of a musty smell (with the occasional whiff of reefer sprinkled in).  And no, the seats and tables don't feel the cleanest (tip: ditch the cloth, fabric seats for some plain old wooden chairs).  However, despite being not nearly as popular as nearby Blackthorn and Yancey's (possibly/probably for the aforementioned reasons), Little Shamrock offers nearly just as much.

The area by the bar has a half dozen or so TV's and tables (including a couple of backgammon tables), as well as a collection of board games you can grab and play.  In addition, there's a little "lounge" area by the bathrooms (it feels like someone's basement) and a back room with a couple of dartboards, some additional tables, a small TV, and an ATM.

Still not all THAT impressive?  You're right, it's not.  The bartender is really nice though.  Oh, and pints of beer are just $4.  Yeah, that's right...$4!  Even if you were to say that's the only good thing about the place, it still was enough to get me to come back a second time.

Of course, it didn't hurt much that the Giants won the two World Series games over the weekend that my buddy and I came here to watch.  Nope.  NOT. AT. ALL.

THREE AND A HALF STARS rounded up for fairly obvious, championship winning reasons. #OrangeOctober

CASH ONLY.
author: Mike L.

description:
About the place: Cool spot, definitely chill...most people will echo that. Inside the lamps look like TGI Fridays and there's a bar plus round tables and chairs. There is also a sofa where the bar tenders dog chills. Dart boards in the back room and decor is eclectic. 

About the price: CASH ONLY. $3 PBR on draft Sunday's. Not sure about other things but likely the same-ish. 

About the food: Doesn't serve food.
author: Neal B.

description:
Came here on a Sunday after the museums in Golden Gate park. I just wanted a place to relax with a pint and charge my batteries (literally and figuratively), and this place was perfect! Cozy, kind of cheesy Irish decor with dirt cheap pints ... What else could you want?

Only qualm is that it is cash only
author: Ben S.

description:
My buddy just moved back to town from grad school and it's always fun talking shop over a beer. The Little Shamrock proved to be a great place to do it in. This bar is over 100 years old and still standing even after a handful of big quakes.

I ordered a more modern snakebite, which was loaded up with a slight cider bias, just the way I like it. There's plenty of seats available and the bartender is responsive when you place your order. Prices are super great too, and I think everything was about $5, but it might have been happy hour.

The location is right at the foot at the park so it's convenient as a stop in between museum shows. A great place to have a conversation during the afternoon, I bet it's just as great or boozing with big groups in the evenings.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
The ladies dominating on a game 7 World Series win!!! 

It's a man's World Series, but these ladies bring the heat every night.  Woot woot!
author: Blue R.

description: I love this bar! Awesome bartenders, drinks, environment and location. The bartenders always make me feel sexy despite my hideous looks. Thanks guys!
author: Ali A.

description:
There's a shelf of board games sometimes blocked by drinkers. Here's some of what it contains: Cranium, Simpsons-something, Connect 4, Candy Land. Or you can bring your own, like we did with "Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Duel at Mt. Skullzfyre" Bill & Ted air guitar gesture Party on Wayne Party on Garth \m/.

"Only the penitent man* will pass." from the door all the way across the corridor-restroom to the commode. The restrooms, by the way, aren't through the dartboard area. All you'll see out that way is a little storeroom of some kegs and stuff.

*man / woman / M-F / F-M / gq / human being / etc.
author: Dan B.

description:
So great to be able to drink in a place that is over 120 years old.

The hot toddy was great after a long day of walking San Fran.

Love the vibe here.
author: Christopher S.

description:
Since moving from London, I'm always on the hunt for a good pub. Not the fancy type that will sell you fish and chips for $25 or call itself a pub simply because they sell some beer. A real pub. No fuss, carpet smelling of good beer, carry more than Budweiser (yuck) kinda place. That being said, Shamrock is just the spot.

Excellent beer selection, chill attitude, old leather-bound chairs, Tiffany lamps, backgammon tables, and darts. That, plus a delicious Irish coffee with the real cream, and good company, what else could a girl want on a Monday night?!
author: Yelena K.

description:
Still smelly after all these years.

For years Yelp reviewers have mentioned the aromas, variously described as mold, musty, vomit, pee, wet cat, septic . . . . 

Alas, the aromas persist.  Perhaps the owner elects not to shell out for plumbing repair and basic cleaning.

Then there's the hostile entitled bartenders . . . 

There are other choices in the Inner Sunset, but given the historic pedigree of Little Shamrock one wishes that its owner would devote some much needed attention to staff attitudes, cleaning and plumbing maintenance.

This could be a great neighborhood bar.
author: Yelp E.

description: Can't think of a better place to spend a rainy afternoon. Darts, games, Guinness.
author: Paige W.

description:
I came here last night with a few friends... a Thursday night. There was not much going on, and this place was not very full at all. We ordered a pitcher of Boddingtons and a greyhound for the lady, then went to the game area. 

There are like no complete games left in the stack. The deck of ginormous cards was complete. Then we did what no other person should ever do... play "chatter matters". Opening up chatter matters, the instructions are vague and there are more cards than you know what to do with. I think some of the cards don't belong. Anyway, we played this game and needed to drink a lot to get this going. This game is barely playable, but I guess you can try with some close friends who you might consider family...

The bathroom is long, but fairly clean.

Beer varies from 3-5 dollars a pint. PBR being the only 3 dollar one I think. Fairly inexpensive. I'm not sure when their happy hours are.

-------------------------------------------------------------
POPCORN:
okay guys, on the yelp app, you'll see that in the tips section, popcorn is mentioned in like 19 (maybe 20) reviews, now that I mentioned it:

THEY DON'T SERVE COMPLEMENTARY POPCORN! but let me repeat that one more time... they DONT serve complementary popcorn.

They sell chips and nuts or something. but as for popcorn, they used to serve it like 3 years ago. 
-------------------------------------------------------------

Overall, it's alright, chill bartenders, cheap alcohol, lots of room to hang out. I'll probably stop in once in a while.
author: Kaje Y.

description:
I'm not afraid to say it--The Little Shamrock is easily one of my favorite bars in the city. From the outside, it looks like just-another typical irish pub. If you give them a chance, though, you'll discover that it's actually so much more.

They have a reasonably good selection of beer on tap for absurdly cheap. My go-to is the $12 pitchers of Deschutes Black Butte Porter. But they have plenty of great, drinkable options if you don't like darker beers. And if you're just looking for cheap beer, the PBR is $8/pitcher. 

The bar has a ton of couches & other seating for big groups, which I love. I can (and have) come here with a group of 15-20 people on a week night. They dont' serve food, but I actually think this is a plus for the bar because they'll let you bring food in instead. There are a ton of good options for food within a couple blocks (gyros, mexican, burgers, thai), so everyone can get what they want and meet here to eat, drink, & be merry. Better yet, they usually have a waitress doing table service, so she'll make sure you're topped off while you eat.

Another of my favorite things about this bar is their collection of games. They have a few typical bar games, like darts in the back room, but they also have a whole shelf of fun boardgames, and several backgammon tables. It's so easy to come here and just hang out for several hours with a group of your friends. 

My introduction to the Shamrock was through the SF Rec Ultimate League. This is the de-facto post-game watering hole for the league, and has been for at least a decade. On a Tuesday or Thursday evening in the summers, you can regularly expect to get a crowd of 20+ jovial Ultimate players sharing pitchers and taking over couches. I think other rec sports leagues also tend to end up here. If you find yourself here on a night where everyone's wearing matching shirts and athletic shorts, go introduce yourself and make some new friends, they'll be friendly.

The Shamrock is in the Inner Sunset, but still reasonably accessible via the 71 or the N. Because it seems out of the way, it doesn't ever get completely crazy-crowded. Perfect!
author: Toby W.

description: Best (dive) bar in the sunset, chill atmosphere & friendly staff!  Whether you are looking for a quiet drink or a good time I highly recommend The Little Shamrock.
author: Meaveen B.

description:
The Little Shamrock is the type of place that I can take my whole family to. That says a lot. My sister would be excited by their board game selection and comfortable seating. My brother would love their abundant supply of playing cards, darts, and of course their cheap drinks and free flowing pop-corn. My mom would enjoy the casual people watching and the charming fireplace and my dad would admire the Welsh flag hanging proudly by the front entrance.

The Little Shamrock is by far my favorite hangout in the area. There's never any pressure to order drinks, and there's a wealth of homey seating in the place. There's a little of everything here to satisfy any group and it's also conveniently located right by the 71 line as well as a plethora of incredible restaurants and food businesses.

If you've never been to The Little Shamrock  - remedy that Waaaaaysap. Not only is it a beautiful example of San Francisco's past - but it's a lovely part of San Francisco present as well.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: I'd heard about the board games, and there IS a whole shelf of them, but they're all missing half the necessary components. Pretty standard bar otherwise, no food. However, if you want to chill on some grungy couches that aren't yours, this place is for you. I'd come try an Irish coffee sometime soon.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Cool little Irish pub we checked out after a trip to the museum, and before our dinner.

Decent drafts, friendly bar tenders... Hard to find anything wrong with the place.

It just doesn't really stand out.
author: Josh D.

description:
This was stop number two for the Sunset Pub Crawl on the ClueKeeper app. The bar has plenty of comfortable chairs and couches-- a real "living room" feel. It's full of history as well as local charm and cheap beer. 

My group would have stayed here all night, except that we were doing a pub crawl and had more puzzles to solve! I'll have to come back again for the full experience.
author: Patricia H.

description: Cash only! Fortunately there's an ATM right outside but avoid the $3.50 fee if you can. Cool place to grab some drinks, talk, and play games. I had an easy time hearing the people I was talking with despite the place being pretty packed.
author: Jamie B.

description:
If you're not in the mood to have your heart melted, poured over a hot griddle and baked into a golden Belgian waffle of life (FULL GLUTEN) doused in whipped cream, quit reading and go take a walk down Cynics Lane. No judgment, I stroll there on occasion. I just wanted to warn you. 

This is a love story. 

Love at first sight is such a lofty (and maybe unreasonable) sensation to claim, but I never promised to be afoot nor bristling with reasonability. The second I stood at the threshold and was swept up in the intangible bear hug of The Little Shamrock, I batted my eyes and fell swiftly in love before one syllable was uttered. 

Some people in San Francisco like a scene and to be seen. Contrary to popular lore, I will ALWAYS prefer to be teleported to a bar that is either 1. a pro-level dive or 2. akin to a living room. The Little Shamrock is the most idyllic interpretation of the latter. 

When the suffocating nerd-douche vibe of SF has worn me down and I cannot bear to listen to another pseudo-CEO/COO/CFO smugly regale me with his latest grand shitty venture into tech, I hide out in a place that feels more like home. This bar is the epitome of that warm, sweetly intoxicated experience, nearly dizzying in all it's unfussy cozy genuineness. 

The first time one of my pals stepped inside The Little Shamrock, she mused, "I love it so much I want to move in." I couldn't agree more. I'd go every day if that little four-leaf clover wasn't going to lovingly destroy my liver.

If you're looking for my heart, it's tucked behind a bottle of whiskey inside a dreamy Little Shamrock on Lincoln Way.
author: Meredith C.

description:
I got a pitcher of beer and it tasted exactly how I would expect, like delicious beer.  The atmosphere seems comfortable, though when I was here, I was told it was much emptier than what's typical.

CASH ONLY.

A fruit fly flew into the depths of my throat, causing me to impulsively gag on my way out & I wasn't charged for the free snack.  Also, the gained knowledge that I apparently walk around with my mouth wide open was free.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
One misty night I walked through the drizzling precipitation that is golden gate park in November. When I emerged, not sure of my surroundings, other than a vague idea of the 71 route and where my friends lived on Ocean Beach, there I first viewed the oasis. 
The Irish Coffee sign implored me to venture inside. I had 8 minutes for the bus anyway. That's where it all began - 1 Irish coffee (best in town) becoming three, and amazing conversation with the regulars. 
You get a good mix of people here - I feel like I'm in a bar in Cambridge, MA. Perhaps the average IQ makes this analogy correct when viewing the typical patrons of nearby Yancy's Saloon and Blackthorne. 
See you there!
author: Jonathan B.

description: Come here all the time as I live in the neighborhood.  That being said, it's hard for it to really ever feel like a locals/regular bar due to all the tourist traffic it gets from the park and its status as the 2nd oldest bar in San Francisco.  $2 PBR draft at happy hour, nice folks behind the bar, darts in the back room, and comfortable seating.  One thing of note though, there's a sign in front of one of the barstools towards the back of the bar labeled "Val's Seat".  Val's a great guy and a long time regular, so unless you want to be viewed as a jerk/amateur, don't try to sit there.  Oh, and like most decent bars in San Francisco, it's cash only.
author: Joshua W.

description: Cheap beer and super chill atmosphere. Only thing that would make this place better is them accepting cards.
author: Karl R.

description:
Walked in for happy hour, and found a very quiet and inviting space for me and my buddies to unwind. Great prices, and an awesome atmosphere--the cushy furniture and board games were totally welcoming.

I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Dan B.

description: Crowded dive bar, cash only. Wish they had a more upscale beer selection, but service was quick and the beer was decent.
author: Patrick M.

description: St patty's destination! It would be even more awesome if they had cheap holiday drink specials.  The Irish coffee is basic. And of course the Irish car bomb. Overall, good vibe.
author: Jade Y.

description:
NB: I've only been here on weekdays in the late afternoon/early evening. Could be a totally different animal on Friday and Saturday nights.

Chill pub atmosphere. Darts, extensive board games, and couches and tables.

I love that they have an old-school phone that they answer. The music has always been good--usually 60s and 70s or 40s -50s inspired. There's a sign that reads, "sarcasm is one of the services we offer." There's a Death Pool. (Zsa Zsa Gabor has to go soon, right?) Sam is great.

It seems like they build regulars here. Need proof? There's a cardboard sign "reserving" Val's seat.

I wish it wasn't cash only, but that's the only bad thing I can say about it. There is an ATM nearby.
author: Diana O.

description: Love this place, it's perfect for playing games with friends. Cozy old fashioned furniture. One night there was chill live music with a bassoon. They've got backgammon tables, tiffany style lamps, cheap drinks, and allow food carry-ins. Perfect spot for hanging out or cards.
author: Joe N.

description: absolute gem of a pub. I love coming here and I'm so glad its in my neighborhood. Cheap beers with a good selection. Good music. Its fun to watch games here because it won't be super crowded like Blackthorn or other bars in the area. The staff is great too. Its cash only though! Although they do have an ATM inside
author: Mandy M.

description:
Sign on a little blackboard at the Little Shamrock bar on Lincoln and Ninth: "Every time someone watches 'Jersey Shore' another book commits suicide." 
In Leah Garchik's Datebook column in the San Francisco Chronicle 1/31/13

Read more: http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/garchik/article/Is-Bates-stay-in-gaol-soon-to-end-4237189.php#ixzz2JfbBWmgp
author: Addadada A.

description: Love Shamrock! It's a great neighborhood bar that always has a good crowd. And for those who play Pokémon Go, it's also a PokéStop.
author: Brooke C.

description: Perfect place to hang out with friends - couches, tables, multiple bathrooms, very good prices. The works!
author: Cecilia A.

description: Charming looking bar. Unhappy bartender who couldn't remember our round of drinks even though the bar was slow. It stank inside. Kind of a septic smell mixed with stale beer and vomit. Expensive drinks!
author: Foodie F.

description: Was ignored at the bar for at least ten minutes while the bartender chatted with friends and served people who came up after me. Had a guy friend order for me and he was served in less than two minutes. Not sure what that's about but since I apparently can't get what I'm there for I will not be returning.
author: Monica D.

description: My friends and I were looking for a chill bar to go to on a misty and rainy SF night. We wanted well priced beer, a chill place to kick back, and a place with music that we didn't have to lose our voices shouting over. We came here and were pleasantly surprised. It's nestled across from Golden Gate Park and it's quite a cozy bar (feels like a living room atmosphere) with ample seating, darts and backgammon tables. We ended up playing an epic game of King's Cup with some awesome people we met at the table next to us. I will definitely be returning and can't wait to see what our next night holds at The Little Shamrock.
author: Justine M.

description:
YES. Totally worth the bike ride from the Mission. 

I love Irish pubs; they're fun, thematic, and the bartenders and patrons somehow seem more down to earth and cooler. 

That and there usually seems to be board games at such establishments!

The Little Shamrock does not disappoint at all. Darts in the backroom (completely full, of course), badgammon tables (i think...don't know how to play), and a healthy assortment of boardgames. We played Apples to Apples ;)

Not to mention, GREAT beer selection on tap. Any place that has Deshutes Mirror Pond Pale Ale, Anderson Valley Boont Amber Ale, AND Deshutes Black Butte Porter on tap is like an instant win for me. The knocker would be if they also had Deshutes Obsidian Stout, oh well (side note: if you know of a bar/pub that does, let me know!)

Aside from that holy trinity of beer, they had other great choices. Pitchers run about $12, not too shabby considering the beer they serve.

So yes Yelp, I want to go back there, I will go back there....
author: Amanda C.

description: Obviously the greatest little bar in all of San Francisco.  This place is historic... and so friendly and fun.  It is my favorite bar in the city.
author: Mike G.

description:
Delightful little place and reminds me of some old Chicago haunts. Watched some March Madness here and it was fairly quiet but fun and definitely has character.

Pretty tiny but cozy with amazing little brass sayings and photographs all over the walls. Beers are cheap and yeah, some game pieces are missing...it's a bar. Get over it.
author: Lauren C.

description: My kinda dive.  Narrow walking room.  Huge bar.  Friendly, older staff and stiff drinks.
author: Carmel U.

description:
This is place is like an actual pub. Not an every-day-is-Saint-Patrick's-day-because-we-have-an-Irish-theme pub (even though the name would make you think the opposite). But like, an actual, honest-to-goodness pub. 

What makes this a pub and not a typical bar? There's lots of tables and seating. There is no loud music, making conversation possible. Not even at night. There is no dancing. There are no guys trying to hit on your girlfriend. It's just a really relaxed vibe, with friends sitting around, playing board games, watching sports, drinking beers, and enjoying themselves. That's what a pub should be, and that's what Little Shamrock is.

Bartenders were amazingly nice too.
author: jared c.

description: So cool to learn that this place is real and not the fictional bar in the John Lescroart novels! Next time I'm in town, I'll definitely check it out.
author: Kathy C.

description: Okay, this place is a must see as it is the oldest bar in san fran that has been in business for 120 years! the current owner has owned it for the last 40. It's an Irish bar. it is old, cozy, dusty, musty, worn, smells of a million years of bar life and a great place for a drink. They have tons of games and backgammon tables too. You will love the vintage cash register. Bring cash as no cards are accepted and the ATM next door charges $3.50 so stick up at your bank first.  Also except for chips there is no food. It's a real bar. Like back in the day when you went to a bar to drink and to a restaurant to eat. Great selection of taps and lotsa hard bar for those wanting more! Longest and narrowest men's room ever! When next in San Fran I will be back fir a pint or two!
author: January S.

description: I love this place for what it is -- down to earth, great variety of drinks, which are cheap. It's been around for well over 100 years so it has great character. Staff are always friendly. Can come here to relax, but can also have a good/fun time.
author: Leah S.

description:
This pub has everything and more. 

But what makes this place truly unique is the clientele and staff. 

Out of all the pubs in this part of the city, from the duck to the lodge, whether you are camping out after B2B, dropping by after sushi or Indian food on 9th, or just suffering through Brian Wilson's coronary-inducing attempts to close out a ball game, the Rock is the place to hang your coat and hat after a long day.
author: Mike V.

description:
The little Shamrock is wonderful. I came here with the friends I've made that aren't over a century old and mothers friends. 

They have board games in the back, of which we played Jenga. When I say we played Jenga I mean we wrote nasty sayings on the blocks and texted the numbers we found. Pro tip, there's a 650 number on one of the blocks that if you text JENGA to, they WILL respond and give you pearls of wisdom. Mother says I'm not allowed to have a cell phone, the radiation will grow hair on my chest, but i digress... mother doesn't want me looking manly, but then again, mother hates men so what does she know? The feather-noddling puddleshlump!

Anyway, the beer.. was beer, no surprise there, but it was the ambiance that made this place great, that and the fact that the company I kept didn't look like another episode of the golden girls.

Mmm mmm for Jenga and fun times!
author: Kevin M.

description:
My husband and I were walking around Golden Gate Park, and after seeing the bar and checking them out on yelp, we decided to stop in. 

The place is really dirty. We've been to a lot of different bars, dive bars at that, but this was pretty bad. They had a backgammon table open, no dice and missing pieces, but we used a dice app and substitute pieces and played. He ordered a Guinness, I ordered an Irish coffee, since they have it advertised so big on the window. Should have had a Guinness... I wonder how long the coffee they had on had been sitting there on the burner... it was terrible. The bartender added a ton of sugar, and the cream was poured in and frothed inside a used, cream-crusted mug. 

The lady bartender was very nice, though, and was generous when adding the Jameson. I was just hoping for the drink to be a little better. I only drank a third of it.

The worst part was the bathrooms. I couldn't believe the state they are in. Try and imagine the worst, smelliest, dirtiest, most terrible bathroom you can... they have two of those.

I don't think we'll be back. :(
author: Sarah L.

description: Loved this friendly, historic Irish pub. Super nice bartender and an easy going clientele. Comfortable soft chairs and a good selection of booze. Great photos on the walls. Hung out for a couple hours to give my weary feet a rest after touring the Botanical Gardens. Glad I did.
author: Diane E.

description:
* Cheap beers and nice selection
* Friendly bartenders (and regulars)
* Mellow music
* Awesome well-worn furniture in a cute living room setting
   in the back with...
   Free wifi! And board games, if you bring friends

Grab some take-out from one of the great restaurants in the neighborhood and come to the Little Sham to get some work done.
author: Cara H.

description:
I don't go bars very often for many reasons... mainly because I DJ in the city and it ends up feeling like you are hanging out at work.  Also because I am cheap... and mostly because the San Francisco culture has turned into a vacuous scene of "seemee"'s and cultural dead ends.

But there is one bar to go to that it feels like home, and I could spend all day.... and it's the Shamrock.  The people are always awesome... it is very much a community bar.  The place is quaint with lots of random, assorted seating.... but here is why it is one of the best in the city:

1)  The best irish coffee in the city, and I will arm wrestle you to prove I am right.

2)  One of the best bloody mary's in the city... easy.

3)  Free popcorn!

4)  Free boardgames.. like.. all of them!

5)  DARTS!

6)  LACK OF PRETENSION!  (people are there to meet and drink... not much else)

7)  One of the main winners that keeps me coming "home"?  The backgammon tables that have cupholders.  Old, dirty, wooden messes that provide me endless fun and witty banter with my compatriots.  I adore it....

8)  JUKEBOX MUSIC

.......and walking in on a rainy Sunday and having an irish coffee like that... 

it can't be beat.  Thanks to Jason T. for reminding me of this place that I somehow found the time to ignore in the last couple months.  Sorry Shamrock!  It won't happen again!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
As I get older I find that I don't hang out at bars as often as I used to.  Of the few that I do find myself going to The Little Shamrock is one of my favorites especially during the day on Saturdays when this place is rather quiet.

I volunteer at various outdoor projects with San Francisco Rec and Parks and sometimes after doing a project within Golden Gate Park I'll drop in either by myself or with friends for a nice cold beer just to chill or get to know someone.  I'm not too picky about my beer; they have Sierra Nevada Pale Ale on draft, and I love them for that.  Their prices are very good too.

Towards the back of the pub they have some really comfortable chairs and sofas.  The sofa was so comfortable on one afternoon that I actually fell asleep while, ironically enough, listening to a friend complain about how her friends don't listen to her enough.  When I awoken some of my other friends were still there, but the friend I had been listening to was already gone.  Oh well, more beer for me!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I, am, a HUNTER.  

I, am, the King of the Forest!  Yes.  I know how to hunt and gather, search and destroy on the interwebs.  With my keen insight and finely tuned intellectual prowess, I was able to latch onto the charm of this place.  Using cunning attributable to the witches of Macbeth, I persuaded the BF to come here on a Tuesday night.  

And.  He.  Loved.  It.  

He, who is a curmudgeon, loved something that I hunted.  I feel so rewarded for my effort!  I am like a kitty that brought home it's first bird or mouse, offering up the bounty proudly as a testament of my evolutionary superiority.  

It was a freezing cold Tuesday night.  I was and still am, a bit sick with the cold.  Maybe slight fever, maybe slight body ache?  Maybe lots tired.  Inside, the bar was well lit in soft lights that were enrobed in stain glass lampshades that hark of days old.  There were many many lamps.  Many.  

The tables and chairs are mismatched the way only time can bring together pieces of discarded furniture.  The ceilings are higher than average, about 14 feet, yet the lowered wooden beams that crossed with the support post gave it a cozy pub-like feel.  The groupings were natural and the clustering was inviting.

We settled down at the back of the pub where a lively fire was burning.  There was a living room like cluster of couches and armchairs in front of the fire, and board games off to the side.  On the walls were an esoteric history lesson in Irish Crests and beer.  The clock perpetually said 5:00.  It was charming.

The Guiness took forever to "draw."  The BF said proper Guiness takes years to pour, and it tastes creamy.  This place gets the stamp of approval.  The beer is fresh, creamy, slow, but still only 16 oz (vs. 20 oz).  Despite this drawback, the BF kept thinking that it felt like being at a pub back home.  Back home, having a pint over a board game costs less than turning on the heating.  I think we'll be going back.
author: Christina C.

description: There's nothing I don't like about this place.  Good beer selection, with very reasonable prices. Pitchers in particular are pretty cheap, given the beers they have on tap.  Though it's definitely more of a pub/beer drinkers' place, I've had terrific girly cocktails here too.   Free popcorn, lots of comfy but battered easy chairs and couches, darts + board games.   Have had many a boozy night here playing Liar's Dice...
author: Heidi M.

description:
I have been throwing down drinks and shooting darts out of the rock since 1993. A WAY diverse gang of peeps plus the normal annual transiant youth from UCSF, GGP Soccer and Frisbee, USF and SFSU...Fine people behind the bar and the knowledge that you are drinking in a place of history. Knowing I could pop back to 1893 and have a beer or hard cider has a bit of "only in SF" kind of feel
For god sakes remember, to the left for the washrooms, to the right for steel tip darts!
author: Joe Bob J.

description:
My friend asked the bartender for a drink recommendation, as she was apparently stuffed to the gills and couldn't put down another beer.  He asked if she had ever had fernet.  I didn't know they served it, and I've always been curious, so I rescinded my Black Butte Porter order and got one as well.  "Don't fight the flavor - because there's a lot of it," he warned.  Wow, it is no joke.  It's like the effect of wasabi mixed with the taste of Chinese medicine.  He definitely recommended the right thing, as it held us over the rest of the night in order to finish via tiny sips.

It was nice and lively for a Friday night, yet wasn't crowded or too loud just to hang out (we had also stopped by Fireside Bar earlier).  I'm also glad and pleasantly surprised that the bartender was not snooty.  I'd say the friendliness and neighborhood-bar-feel is right up there with Minibar SF, which is fantastic.

And omg did Keane L. say Taboo?!  I fucking LOVE that game.  Where was I in 2007?!
author: Jenn C.

description:
A local favorite, charming, comfortable, and fantastic. A neighborhood bar for over a century. Not many neighborhood bars have this kind of charm, dumpiness, and characters.

2nd oldest bar in San Francisco!

Stop in for a pint, some fucked up converstion, scrabble, chess, checkers, hell they got Candyland for @#$& sakes.

Keep in mind, this is a local spot, and Inner Sunset folks roll baby. We roll.

Much less junkies that Silver Spur. Go there for coke.
author: Enoch K.

description:
We were out house hunting in the area and happened upon this little charmer. It definitely brings a local feel, with loads of character. They have a wide array of games to choose from and interesting seating.

An eclectic crowd of folks, with crude conversation on the lips (really, what more could you want?!!). Decent beer selection as well.The only drawback we found was that they didn't take cards. This will easily be our haunt if we move to the area.

Uptight people, keep passing by. I have a feeling you wouldn't like it here anyways.
author: Kim T.

description:
I really enjoy going to the Little Shamrock. It's always a very warm and cozy place to go and just kick back with friends. The fireplace is in a section with a few couches and chairs, and tables with board games all over.

It's a tradition to come here and play Jenga because people have added their own phrases to the Jenga blocks, which makes for quite a unique Jenga experience.

Also, all the bar tenders here a really chill, and I'm stoked because I just got a phone call saying my quote got picked for the quote of the week, so now I can come and get a free drink!
author: Josh L.

description:
Local flavor is fun and comfortable, and you are bound to always hear a fun conversation from other visitors. Cash-only isn't a surprise in the Sunset area, but the selection of games in the seating area makes up for it. One trip to the ATM beforehand provides 3-4 hours of entertainment, fun, and delicious drinks.  Mixed drinks always came in strong, and the service was friendly, but not overly kind. Start talking brews, and their eyes light up with joy

Despite being one of the oldest bars in San Francisco, it certainly remains a dive bar.
author: Nathan O.

description:
This place is a lot closer to what pubs actually are back in the UK. 

I personally liked the ambiance of this place because of the seats and couches. However, what I don't like is that it can get quite crowded at this bar and therefore loses its quiet coziness. Instead, it becomes a busy hangout spot that is filled with med students with large backpacks, knocking people upside the head when they make a quick turn or a bunch of sweaty, embarrassingly-dressed  Ultimate  Frisbee teams having a beer over their "win" (though, in regards to playing ultimate frisbee....is anyone really a "winner"?)

I think I would've liked this place a lot more had it had a pool table. That is all.
author: Rylan C.

description:
I adore this bar. 

It's a piece of history, a place to play board games, an unassuming crowd, free-flowing popcorn, cheap drinks, antique furniture, and extremely cool bar staff. 

Basically, a sweet refuge from a shitty world.
author: Megan W.

description:
I had reviewed this place before, but i had mixed up this joint with Yancy's.

LITTLE SHAMROCK bills itself as the oldest Irish bar in town, and who am i to doubt that? The beer is beer, the Irish coffees are phenomenal, and boardgames in the back are oh so delightful, and the backgammon...well, i don't play backgammon. But if i did, i'm sure i'd appreciate it.

I have spent many an afternoon/evening/night here, and i'm sure that if they opened mornings, i'd spend a few of those here too.

The thing that separates this bar from many many others is how not packed it is, how comfortable and cozy it is, how delicious the Irish coffees are, and how personable the staff is. Definitely a neighborhood bar, and proud to be part of that neighborhood.
author: Phuong M.

description: This my favorite place in the neighborhood, and it was one of the first businesses in the Sunset. Everything in here is old, in the best possible way- they even have a clock that stopped when the 1906 earthquake hit. Plenty of cozy seating and board games to loan. Beer selection is excellent and cocktail prices are lower than what you'll find in the Mission (but not "Artisinal"). It's also a good place to watch a Giants game without having too much of a sports bar feel. All in all, it's exactly the type of old-time non-pretentious bar that I love.
author: Mark H.

description: A quaint spot. I played board games there and didn't get a drink. I had never been, but I'll go back and get a drink. A great San Francisco Irish-themed bar.
author: Denise C.

description:
Great dive, cheap pitchers, good selection of beer on tap and boardgames!!!

Fact or Crap and Cranium.  My friends and I will battle it out when it comes to cranium, sorry if we're too loud.  Very laid back.  CASH ONLY.  Bartenders are very friendly.
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
This may be the most comfortable bar I've ever been to.  So comfortable that I usually get a warm numb feeling, melt into my chair, and before I know it three hours have gone by.  It feels both divey and classy at the same time.  The lamps are awesome and so are are the bartenders.  You can kind of get lost just staring at all the stuff on the walls.

They have these really old wooden backgammon tables against the back wall and I learned how to play here.  Three are plenty of other board games to choose from and a back room for darts too.

So far this place is my favorite bar in the Inner sunset and the only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because of the beer selection (it's not bad but just average) and that it lacks a pool table.
author: Paul W.

description: It's located right by public transportation, which is great after a night of drinking. The drinks are affordable. The staff is friendly and the atmosphere is laidback. I like the living room feel in the back of the place. They even let me charge my phone while I waited for my bus. I'll definitely go back.
author: Rigel A.

description:
Coming from Pittsburgh I have a real affinity for dive bars.  When I moved into the sunset this was the first bar I entered and am I ever so glad I did.  There is a great mix of regulars and new people alike and everyone is extremely friendly and welcoming.  The bartenders are funny, quick to serve a drink, and enjoy getting to know the patrons.  And the prices; pretty much as cheap as they get in expensive ass San Francisco.

Sure the place is a little dingy, and there is dust on the lights, and grime in the bathroom.  But its a dive bar for God's sake; just the way a dive bar is supposed to be!!
author: T.C. J.

description:
Little Shamrock is by far one of my favorite gaming bars.  If I'm looking for a low key, don't feel like hanging out in my living kind of night I head to the Little Shamrock.  My night usually involves walking to the bar, grabbing a beer, stop at the free popcorn machine and then heading straight back to the dart room.   There are two dart boards, plenty of chairs and a stereo up in the corner that you can turn to whatever station you please (that is of course if you are alone, I would consult with the other parties before changing the station.  Yeah that means you, I'm Mr. Shamrock and can come in and change the station whenever I damn will please.)  

The crowd is usually very laid, with the exception of that man above but he didn't stay too long.  If you aren't into darts they have boggle, scrabble, connect 4, Simpson's clue, checkers, chess, backgammon, etc.  You get my drift.  If you don't want to fight the crowd at Yancy's and are craving more of a coffee shop vibe head down to the "rock."
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
This bar has a charming ambience - cozy, rustic with a mix of different sofas n chairs, games, fireplace and good drinks!  Great place to be with friends -  play board games n dart  at the back of the room. Definitely has become my favourite Friday night hangout bar in my Inner sunset neighborhood! 

Cons: Only cash, n a $7 down the drain shot (don't remember the name, but it was more of diluted cranberry juice)!

Will be back next time to try out the Irish coffee.
author: Payal B.

description: I am firmly in my thirties now so I want my neighborhood Irish bar to be comfortable, friendly, and fun but not too rowdy.  Also, a decent Irish coffee helps.  The Little Shamrock fits the bill!  Plus, they have board games, which I can get behind.
author: Shauna L.

description:
I really have no words other than "WHOA!" for this bar. The moment I walked in the bar smelled like an antique shop and there were all kinds of little tables and chairs. Towards the back there was a great little nook with sofas and a huge round table. It was amazing in there!
I was told this was one of the oldest bars in San Francisco, and I couldn't help but be proud to live in the same neighborhood as this establishment.

Check it out for history's sake anyways. I wasn't disappointed one bit!
author: Angie P.

description: I love places with heritage and this place is just full of that.  SF's second oldest bar and going strong.  I love the homely interior and the very reasonably priced drinks.  Great beer selection plus killer white russians and car bombs.  Spent so many nights here getting that warm feeling.  Cool seating with a nice look over toward the park.  No jukebox but the bartenders do a pretty good job managing the tunes.  It's cash only, probably cuz they couldn't hook up a credit card slider to that 1800s cash register.  It's my favorite bar in the area and there's a lot of 'em around.  This one keeps me coming back.
author: Sin F.

description: Great place to go. Went there on a monday night with my friends and the bartender made a great Tom Collins for my friend, and she was just really awesome. Forgot my ID and she was gracious about not serving me, not rude as some others can be. The atmosphere was really awesome as well. Can't wait to go again with my ID.
author: Samantha C.

description:
This is a quirky little place that delighted me. First thing I noticed when walking is that none of the furniture matched. Second was the two or three group of folks playing backgammon while enjoying a few pints of their favorite beers. 

The group I was with settled down and found a great spot to enjoy ourself. We were coming from dinner and just wanted a little night cap. So we ordered 4 Irish Coffees. The bartender banged out 4 tasty Irish Coffees and we proceeded to enjoy the end to our evening. 

At one point I noticed 4 spunky girls with darts in their hand making their way to the back section of the bar. My assumption was there was a dart board. Hmmmmmmm Love places with dart boards.  Going to have to check out more of the Shamrock has to offer!
author: Ryan B.

description:
We were trying to kill time before it was time to head to the de Young museum, and Yelped just happened to suggest this bar to us.

$4 beer, darts, comfy couches. I like!

There is a DART ROOM...how exciting and FUN!

The environment may seem a little eerie (dark dusty corners and green bathrooms) but have no fear, The Little Shamrock is as harmless as it is fun. Didn't I mention a dart room???

I love their furniture.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
The Little Shamrock is dope with a capitol D, come for the drinks, stay for the games that get funner and more interesting as the night moves on (and you continue to consume beverages). 

Another thing I'm a fan of is the fireplace, dope for a cold rainy night. The general atmosphere of the place is pretty darn cozy, lots of wood and old bar mirrors, right up my alley. 

Give me a down home pub with wood paneling and old bar mirrors with patrons that have names like ol' walleye over a place with uber-chic pseudo furniture and dudes in collared shirts named Dieter any day of the week.
author: Tommy P.

description:
Drinks = good
Board games = cool!
Decent seats.
Nice bartenders.
Good lighting.
Old-school feel though.

Good times had by all!

Parking is a pain.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I like the Little Shamrock a lot and I wish it was 5 blocks from house instead of 15! Its just a laid back place with well poured Guinness and dart boards. I wish they didn't have televisions but these days there isn't much you can do about that... 

Oh yeah and:
$5 for a pint of Guinness!
author: Alex W.

description:
Found this place in  random way; happy I did.

GREAT neighborhood spot that serves Guinness in a slightly less frosty manner than you can usually find in SF...not sure if this is intentional but it is good.
author: Christopher L.

description:
The Little Shamrock is a nicely laid-out pub that provides a homey, lived-in feel while still presenting itself as clean while not overly sterile.  Less rectangular and closer to square in shape, it gives off an inviting cafe-like feel.  The shape of it also allows for ample front windows, allowing natural light to more effectively penetrate most of the seating area.  Further back and at night, lighting is tastefully done with hues of green at the bar gently blending to orange-ish earth-tones towards the rear.  A nice art collection compliments the walls, while the ceilings are tastefully accented with a sizable assortment of stained-glass lamps.  

The clients are mixed, local, and friendly.  I cruised in, commented on a discussion involving past loves and mistakes made, and I was instantly one of the crowd.  Very little pretension, with insularity bordering on nil.  The jukebox and the selections coming out of it were nothing short of perfect for the Saturday afternoon I was visiting, and the ratio of music-amplification to ambient-noise never made conversation a problem.  Board games are available for use to patrons, and it didn't look like you'd have trouble finding a friendly opponent.

The barmaid was nice, and the selection of beer was about on par with any other well-trafficked pub in the city.  They don't cook here, but a popcorn machine provides free relief from the munchies.  If you want something more substantial, a host of restaurants can be found a block over on Irving Street.

The really nice thing about this place?  Despite it's pretty close proximity to USCF, most of the crowd were grown-ups.  There weren't any boisterous kids present, and their usual twenty-something mating game along with the bad vibe that follows it around was thankfully absent.  It's one of the first pubs I've stumbled into in a long time that I'll consider a home away-from-home.  Look for me at the bar on Sunday afternoons.....I'll be one of many with a pint in my hand, and a smile on my face...
author: Mike W.

description:
Pro: four beers for $16.
Con: smells like pee.

Pro: very accommodating place, with friendly patrons who switched to a smaller table so we can fit, to a friendly waitress who checks in often.
Con: smells like pee, and cash only.

Pro: Guinness on tap.
Con: smells like pee, cash only, and waitress seems to be on her first week.

Con: smells like pee, cash only, waitress seems to be on her first week, and people with BO.

Con wins.  Maybe we'll go back when it's a colder day and there is more air ventilation.
author: Jenny L.

description:
It's a pretty decent pub. There's not a whole lot that's noteworthy about it, as far as I can tell. The floor is uneven in the back. Basically you can order drinks here.

The bathroom graffiti isn't even that interesting.

It's cash only, so be aware of that.
author: Cristopher B.

description: Love the furniture here and they have board games for you to borrow. Great beer selection and it's well priced.
author: M R.

description: I'm a dive bar kinda gal.  Give me cozy, give me low key, give me a Guinness.  This place is my favorite dive bar in the city.  I love the combination of different size dining tables surrounded by chairs, and coffee tables surrounded by sofas and loveseats. The fireplace is a plus. I also appreciate that they let you bring food in from any of the surrounding eateries. The staff here is really friendly.  Just don't sit in Val's seat!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Popcorn ? nice. Cheap drinks that get the job done but I'm still able to get up at a decent hour the next morning? Yes. 

Overall atmosphere is comfy, charming place. A great meet -up or a destination spot.

Fireplaces? Yes. Perfect for those hazy sf days ;)
author: Amanda S.

description:
I don't even live in the Bay Area any more, but I still have fond memories of this place. A friend of mine worked over at Park Chow, and we used to come over here because everybody knew her name... that's right, just like Norm from "Cheers" -- except she's much hotter.

Fond memories: sitting with my vodka tonic transfixed to the tv (actually the entire bar was), as Michael Phelps won his 8th Gold Medal in the 08 Olympics. 
Kicking this guy's ass in backgammon at one of the tables.
Giving a friend the "Everyone Poops" book for her birthday and reading it out loud, Romper-Room style in the back room. 

That's the type of place this establishment is -- a place for building memories.... aaaahhhhhhh!
author: mariel v.

description: Any bar with Darts (www.sfda.org) and Guinness on tap automatically gets four stars from me.  I'd give it 5 but the bathrooms are always stinky.  It's right near the park; a perfect place to pop in after spending the day basking.  Along with a dedicated darts area they have games galore.
author: Jersey M.

description: You have to love the Shamrock for everything it is.  I go here fairly often, and always have a great time.  A small, traditional Irish pub, with an excellent yet divey ambiance.  My only hope is that the night bartenders would be a little more friendly, but what can you do?
author: Bridget B.

description:
Definitely the kind of bar I enjoy. Old, charming, never too busy, decent prices, nice bartenders. Great place to take a group of friends where you can actually talk and hear each other. 

Kudos to Mr. Bartender for the free cheetos that he gave me and my friend. Seriously though, the broken popcorn machine either needs to be fixed or taken away - the presence of the machine taunted a very drunk and hungry Courtney.
author: Courtney S.

description:
Ya! I'm a fan
One star less cuz no credit cards but hey I must admit, this is a nice friendly cozy bar, darts in back, been here a few times & never knew that room existed, sign I must have been having a good time.
 Bar staff very friendly & I never got that new to a bar glare from anyone there.
Very nice local feel & decor was pleasing to the eye, allot of character which cannot be done over night.
I'll be back..
author: Jennifer R.

description:
Nicey-wicey-cheapy-funny-divey bar for locals and newbies alike, but more of the former.

Cheap drinks - CHECK
Divey atmosphere (yeyah!) - CHECK
Free popcorn - CHECK
Accessible by public transit (6, 71, N), parking and walking - CHECK
Groovy board games on the tables - CHECK
Spacious - CHECK
Oozing with character - CHECK
Awesomely friendly and chatty bartenders - CHECK
Friendly, unpretentious and laid back patrons - CHECK
Is it an authentic Irish Bar? - CHECK / UNCHECK
Irish coffee on a cold, winter night - CHECK! CHECK! CHECK! CHECK!
Dart Board - CHECK
Me ever winning at the Dart Board - UNCHECK
Good for groups and 1-on-1 - CHECK
Tacky charm and oh-so lovable furniture - CHECK
Shot contests - CHECK x INFINITY

... me winning a shot contest... I'll let you know when I'm passed out on the floor with an Irish charm stuck up my nose.
author: Amit S.

description:
I spent the last year and a half in England, and when I got back to SF, I climbed out of the taxi and one of the bartenders came running out and said "Jason! Come on in and get a beer!" 

You don't need another paragraph to know that this is the kind of place where you make friends and enjoy your time with an extremely friendly staff and regulars. The beer selection is amazing, too, without a doubt my favourite pub in the city!
author: K S.

description:
small irish pub, came here specifically bc they had boardgames. 

ATMOSPHERE:
Like a casual Irish pub feel. Some couches and coffee tables and small regular tables in addition to the bartop.
author: Angela L.

description: Great place to have a brew and play backgammon
author: Ryan B.

description: I have not visited yet in person, but I still feel like I have been here dozens of times. This bar stars in a series of books by John Lescroart. The series was launched in 1989 and features Dismas Hardy, who works at this bar. Paging through the other reviews, nobody has mentioned the connection yet. Has anybody who visits this bar ever read these books? Anyone else feel they are qualified to make a connection or a comment on this?
author: Gail E.

description:
The best thing about this place is the large built-in backgammon tables.  Great darts space too.

A classic pub.  Decent selection of beers at decent prices, free popcorn. If you're in the mood for a dark pub with multiple large-screen TV's showing a Giant's game or other sports, then this is the place for you.
author: Fred W.

description: Great place to watch sports! Really friendly staff, and not too crowded.
author: Lucy L.

description:
There is something about the Little Shamrock that makes me want to scrub down in Clorox after being here, but in a sort of fulfilling way. The Little Shamrock LOOKS like cigarette smoke smells, if that makes any sense. Fortunately, I am a social smoker.

For a place that has "IRISH COFFEE" splashed across the facade, the "IRISH COFFEE"s are pretty inconsistent. I've had great ones here and (as was the case yesterday) I've had horrible ones here. By horrible I mean luke warm with clumpy cream. But I'll hand it to homie behind the bar- he's got that Bushmills:coffee:cream ratio down. 

Bottom line: I'll be back for IRISH COFFEE on a cold day if I happen to be in Golden Gate park, but one more of those Irish Coffeecicles and I'm over this Shamrock for good.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Love this place.  My husband and I, including a few or our buddies aren't really into clubs and absolutely prefer bars and we liking trying out new ones every now and then but we decided to try this place out and we haven't went anywhere else since.  We absolutely love his place.  The atmosphere is relaxing not to mention they have a darts room in the back!  What's better than being a little tipsy, hanging with your buddies and shootin' darts in a secluded room?  It's awesome.

We usually stop by this place once or twice a week when we get the chance.  If you like bars like I do, you have to check this place out!
author: Jenny F.

description:
The Little Shamrock = the most fun I've ever had waiting for the bus. If you're trying to catch the 6 or the 71 anytime after 6 p.m., you're looking at a 20 minute wait, at least.

My suggestion is to turn your frown upside down and grab a beer at the Little Shamrock...with a seat by the windows you can keep an eye on the road and not freeze to death on Lincoln Street. 

The bartenders are extra friendly and the bar is cozy with heavy wooden tables and chairs. I was drinking beer and became insanely jealous when I saw the bartender make some Irish Whiskeys with homemade whipped cream. I think in the end we were there for the time of at least 3 buses. We went home happy and warm.
author: carrie c.

description:
This place has a room with chairs, tables, and two dartboards in the back, which is vitally important for one reason only: I won at darts.  Three times.  In a row.

(I don't really care if my exceptionally tall friend was letting me win, a thought which did cross my mind, because I like to win.  Period.  However, it could also be that a couple beers and a couple glasses of wine throughout the evening helped quell my omnipresent anxiety at Not Being The Best At Everything.)

As I recall (it seems like forever since I've had free time), beers (good beers) were $4, the bartender had a charming accent, and the whole place was dingy but comfortable.  It's close to Golden Gate Park, a good stop-off after CAS Nightlife, and close to the N-Judah, and Pacific Catch/Marnee Thai/Park Chow.

AND I WON.  I WON I WON I WON, TAKE THAT.
author: Jennie K.

description: Super chill. Casual and comfortable with friendly bartenders. Cash only, but can bring food from outside since there is no kitchen.
author: david l.

description:
Messy doesn't begin to say it.

The place looks a New Orleans dive at 4AM....after a gas explosion in the popcorn machine.  There is popcorn debris embedded in every section of carpet, couch, wall crevasse, and vertical surface, and from the smell of it, it's been there a while.

The place is cluttered with old games, lamps, and spiderwebs of old extension cords, all connected to a tacky lighting device.

This is enough to scare away the cops, fire inspectors, and people from outside the neighborhood.  Personally, I hightailed it back to the Tenderloin for something a bit more classy.

People seemed to be having a good time there, mostly talking in groups, unassuming.  You can wear a T-shirt and old jeans, a mohawk, you don't have to shower, it's okay.
author: Gil S.

description:
+1 for being in my neighborhood
+1 for the good music 
+1 for the trivial pursuit entertainment + other games available
+1 for the non-pretenciousness
-1 for the weird raggedy couch in the back with the weird spring sticking out that was hurting my back.. .


OHHH, and go to the bathroom on the left door. fucking wild! :D
author: Jennie L.

description:
A bar that will provide such a basely positive experience that it'd make even people-who-don't-like-bars happy.

Little Shamrock hits squarely on the intangibles of the bar-going experience: atmosphere, music, light/lighting, whimsy, and a pleasantly interactive barstaff.

You can have a conversation there without raising your voice or get loud and dance on tables -- I experienced both during a single visit.

Recommended? = Sure!
author: Chris R.

description: Cute, little neighborhood bar.  Cool place for a pint and a game of darts.  Cash only.
author: Marlie H.

description:
Where else in the world would you get a Long Island Ice Tea with fruit juice in it?

This place sucks! It has been one of the worst pubs i have ever visited. My friend ordered a rum and coke- it was all rum and no coke.

The long island ice tea was sent back and i was told that this is how it is made there- weird!

My beer was not cold and had no head and  just did not taste right. They dont serve any food/snacks and dont accept cards.  
I wouldn't go back even if they offered a free drink
author: Andy r.

description:
I hate Taboo. I hate it.

My ancestors didn't immigrate here on old Chinese junks so that I could be told what I could or could not say. This is America, dammit. No plastic card is going to stop me from describing "baseball" with the word, "pitcher." Burn in hell, Hasbro. (I'll still love you for G.I. Joes and Transformers.) 

The Little Shamrock was a cool place for Yelp gamenight. They took drink orders from our tables, and had free (though limited) popcorn for consumption. They don't take credit, but there's an ATM outside. The bartender made sure we were cool to drive before we left. 

I'm constantly dumbfounded (pause for humour) by the large number of Irish pubs in the Richmond/Sunset.
author: Keane L.

description:
What I learned at Yelp Game Night:

Unbogged is not in the Scrabble dictionary
Masturbation is a bad habit while masturbating is a leisure activity
Drunken guys do not think that Denzel Washington is the epitome of cool
The tastiness of stale popcorn is highly correlated to ones' level of drunkenness

Oh, also that the Little Shamrock is a pretty cool bar with a very chill vibe. Lots of gamers, both casual and hardcore, enjoying board games over a glass of beer. And sports enthusiastics checking out the multiple TVs at the bar. And hungry folks waiting for the kernels to pop.

Psst... remember it's at 9th & Irving and not 20 & Taravel.
author: .elin f.

description: Second oldest known bar in the city.  Great prices, great beers, darts, fireplace, board games, lots of tables to bring food in, nice old atmosphere for an old bar.  The best place to go before or after dinner in the Inner Sunset.
author: Nick F.

description:
This here will be my new Cheers. Just like the t.v. show, everyone here will know my name. I'll be the drunk guy everyone will leave alone after 4 shots, 3 beers, and a variety of mix drinks people will buy me. I will make my own board game rules, I have 2-5-7-4-8. 

I win.

I WILL BE YOUR YELP DRINKING BUDDY.

*did anyone see the yelp sticker on the glass window by the bar. AWESOME!
author: Stanley K.

description:
I had a great time here this weekend. This was our last stop in a spontaneous bar crawl in the Inner Sunset. Lots of random funky couches and games. We played backgammon for at least an hour. Not enough white pieces but popcorn made for a decent substitute (until someone started eating them). 

So yes... They serve hot buttery popcorn for free! Serve yourself in the back left corner. 

Bartenders were really nice and let us chug  the rest of our pitchers before kicking us out. 

Didn't go to the bathroom here, but I should have because as soon as we got outside I HAD TO PEE! I cannot pee outside, due to my disgust with bodily waste. No amount of drip drying and aim can keep it off me, so I'd rather my bladder burst. Shell station was closed, outhouse was locked, so I had to "run" the 9 blocks back to a real bathroom. So even if I had gone to the bathroom here, I wouldn't be able to give a real review because all I would say is, "It felt SOOOO good to pee!!"

Also they have some bomb beers on tap, oatmeal stouts and such!
author: Ali R.

description:
Whenever someone doesn't believe that I'm tough and I'll fight him (i.e., all the time), I tell the story about how I got a black eye.

Then I make up a bullshit story about me making out with some chick's boyfriend at Zeitgeist or something tough-sounding and her throwing her drink on me and me going all ninja on her ass and totally fucking her up and somehow getting a black eye in the process.

No one ever believes that story for some reason. But I really did get a black eye once. I had beaten my little sister in five consecutive games of backgammon and was getting cocky. She made a bad move, and I told her that wasn't the smartest thing she could have done. She got frustrated and threw the dice at me. I went all ninja on her ass and totally fucked her up and somehow got a black eye in the process. 

Or rather, I said something rude back at her and got up to leave. She tried to shove me in the back, but I turned around at exactly the wrong moment and got shoved in the eye. 

(This probably doesn't sound like it has much to do with The Little Shamrock, and I promise it will in a second. But if you are impatient and just want to know my opinion: yes. It is a chill Irish bar with beer and an amazing selection of board games and board game tables, so I like it.) 

Anyway, after suffering the indignity of receiving a black eye at the hands of my little sister, I retired from backgammon for a few years. Until yesterday. I was trying to go to bar night at Canvas Gallery across the street, but I couldn't find any of my people except one, and the open mic comedians were a problem, so we headed to The Little Shamrock instead. 

Without even getting drinks, my friend beelined for the backgammon table. I was like "Oh yes, I used to play a mean backgammon in the day. It's ON, bitch, and you are going DOWN."

It wasn't long before he realized that a) I wasn't tough and b) I didn't even remember how to play backgammon. I had to call my sister.

"Hey Caroline, remind me how to play backgammon. ... Yes, I remember. ... I REMEMBER. ... okay OKAY! Now tell me how to play backgammon..."

Then it was on. Despite my limitless backgammon talent, I was no match for my novice friend, who thoroughly whupped my ass. Unlike SOME people, I didn't choose to PUNCH HIM IN THE EYE when I lost. But this time was just a warning. If it happens again, I'm SO gonna go all ninja on his ass and totally fuck him up and somehow get a black eye in the process.
author: Liz G.

description:
It's a game bar.

A gay bar?

No, you idiot a game bar.

What do you mean it's a singles bar where guys are constantly trying out lame lines on gullible women?

No, you fool.  A game bar.  Like a place where you can drink beer and play board games all night. 

Really?

Yeah, you nincompoop.  Me A. did bite me though.   Twice.

Does that usually happen?

I'm not sure.
author: Beau G.

description:
Big shout out to Matthew S. for suggesting this place too :D
Yay Matthew S :D
Hip hop hooray to ya!

Fuckin perv guy, Jackson, who I want to beat up. Who is he?! Someone from yelp introduced me to him so fess up! He deserves to get his stupid arse kicked! 

Sweet bartender.

Hot
hot hot hot
and I don't mean in a sexual way.
It's getting hot in here so take off all your clothes.
Cool bathrooms.
Reasonably priced drinks.
GAMES galore!
author: Aim E.

description: This place is amazing! awesome seating, couches and tables everywhere, drinks were served fast
author: Sarah T.

description:
Wednesday: 12/272006 
- 12:08a Arrival
- 12:55a Departure

It's a cool little neighborhood bar close to Golden Gate Park -- very much like a typical Irish bar.  One of the guys I am currently dating works a few blocks away so I met him when he got off work at 11p at The Little Shamrock.  After a day trip to the snow learning how to snowboard, I didn't want the fun to end and wanted to take advantage of having the whole week off from work, so I drove my sleepy self to The Sunset.  

$3.00 PBRs and about 10 other beers on tap!  There wasn't a big crowd when I got there (10 men and 4 women), mostly regulars who knew each other.  The bartender, Drew, was really friendly -- he asked me how I was doing and what I did for Christmas.   There are plenty of board games available to play by the fireplace including Chess and Backgammon.  

It's great that this bar supports Yelp (sticker at the bar) :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Stumbled into the Little Shamrock for refuge from the afternoon chill and ended up wasting away the rest of the day sipping hot-totties and lounging the ancient yet comfy furniture.  

I really like this bar because it reminded me of my favorite dive bar back in Allston, MA (the Silhouette) with the free popcorn & darts... except The Little Shamrock is way cleaner!  

They also had a stack of board games by the fireplace... which I would have loved to have played, but ALL the pieces were missing.  So we opted for chilling in the dart room & writing all over the chalkboard walls.  Kudos if you can locate the dart room... more than once a someone wandered back there and was like, "Never in my years here have I noticed this room."
author: Liz T.

description: Cheap drinks, cozy couches, friendly bartenders, and lots of TVs.  A great dive bar, and a good way to end a walk around Inner Sunset or Golden Gate Park.
author: Bill H.

description: Bf and I came here for a beer one afternoon and the bar itself is nice and cozy. Bartender gal was nice. She told us it was one of the oldest bars in SF and it even was up and running during prohibition because it was so far out from everything at the time that they simply didn't care to shut it down. Anyway, cool bar, would come back!
author: Lynn C.

description: Built in backgammon tables and great beers on tap this is your spot and they also got plenty of tv's with all kinds of sports on them.
author: Chris D.

description:
Meandering around before Nightlife at the California Academy of Sciences, a friend and I bellied up to the bar, which was pretty much full of locals.  We definitely stood out from the rest of the pack.  

It is conveniently located near the Golden Gate Park and they have Guinness on tap, which makes me a SUPER happy camper.  Plus, the place has a lot of local character.  There are photos on the wall, which show what the bar looked like back in the day...we ended up there for a nightcap after Nightlife, as well.  

The sofas and chairs seem to have seen better days, but the atmosphere is good and the drinks are not expensive.  3 solid stars.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
This is the place that I take my brother to throw darts and play backgammon when he is in town.  This is the place that I go when I want to drink and write in peace.  This is the place I go with a rowdy bunch to play trivial pursuit and show off how smart we are.

This is one of my favorite bars in the city.  It is not a place to go out dancing or to find "the one" but it is a good bar.  Drinks are inexpensive, and it is never too full to get good service.

They keep the free popcorn and board games well stocked, but you might have to search for enough dice to play your game.  There are several sofas around low tables, a fireplace, and two bathrooms, although only one is marked.  

The back room has two dartboards and it's own stereo that you can tune in and turn up.  Remember, bathrooms to the left, darts to the right.  Lots of people wander through the dart room in search of relief.
author: Quinn S.

description: This was one of the last stops on my sunset bar hop last night.  It is a fun little cozy bar, with cool antique furniture, backgammon tables, and a board game nook.  Just had a vodka shot, stayed for a little while and attempted to answer the obscure Balderdash trivia questions , and then headed home.   I would include it on my next sunset bar crawl.
author: Madison M.

description:
My all-time best quote regarding The Little Shamrock.... "this is the bar that the people who sell fake pot on Haight street go to 'after work'"
The complete set of teeth-to people ratio is slightly off. The lighting is too bright to create any kind of seediness from the sadness. The popcorn is good, but you feel guilty picking kernels outta your teeth, when others have so few. The drinks are strong, the glasses may not be clean. The couches are filthy. A little slice of tenderloin in the inner-sunset.
