2 Star? the alcohol they serve makes up for the ambiance they provide, a catch 22
author: B.dot P.

description:
The 2nd oldest bar in the city (who woulda thunk?) is still on my shortlist of favorite San Francisco bars.  Reasonable prices, a fireplace in the back, couches throughout, backgammon and darts, free popcorn, and nary a hipster in sight.  And everyone I take there has pretty much the same reaction: "Wow, this place is pretty cool!"   

A neighborhood bar in the best sense of the word, it's a bastion of old-school San Francisco, which seems to be disappearing at an alarming rate.
author: Jen D.

description: Ssllooww zzzzzzz.  And everywhere dirty.  Couches dirty, table dirty, carpet dirty, bathroom dirty.  Dirty dirty dirty uugghhh.
author: Pam S.

description:
I was here once with a friend that lives nearby. I always knew there were some cute little pubs elsewhere in the city, but I'm so sucked into the vortex that is the Mission that I miss out sometimes.
Well, the Little Shamrock was great! It's relaxing with couches & comfy chairs as well as some lively eye candy. Helloooo handsome!
I was there with the activist/brainiac group of folks I know, so they were talking about changing the world and writing papers and shit. Luckily, there were some games calling out to me, so I was able to sneak off and have some downtime. I especially like the fact that this bar seems an awful lot like my mom-mom's house...antiquey, cozy and plenty of booze around. As I recall they also make a spot on Irish Coffee!
author: Colleen B.

description:
I live in the mission. There is a particular friend of mine from high school who I have always convinced to come to my neighborhood to hang out. One Friday night, I was reluctantly convinced to come to her neighborhood. I asked if there was a cool, laid-back place where we could go and I wouldn't have to fight through a huge crowd to get a beer. This was her suggestion.

She was right. I think my Anchor only cost $4, the bartender was always quick to get to me, it wasn't crazy loud and although there was a crowd, we could still find comfortable pieces of furniture to lounge around on. I've got too much love for my neighborhood to make this a regular place for me, but it was certainly an enjoyable experience and I didn't remotely mind riding my bike all the way from the mission to get to it. I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Jen R.

description:
I really like this place for the most part, it  is a great local dive with free darts.  My one request for improvement is this: 

Please stop making last call at 1:20am and then continue to harass me about finishing my drink until 2am (especially on St. Pattys, WTF!!). Are you Irish, Mr Shamrock, I think not.
author: Justin F.

description:
My dad tried to teach me backgammon a few times as a child but my A.D.D got in the way. Miraculously, a trip to the Little Shamrock along and a few jacks and coke later, my husband not only taught me to play but I whooped his booty! 

This place reminds me of the well lit intellectual pubs in London. The vibe is one of a living room. There is free popcorn and the layout is conducive to conversation or games. It can get lively as the night goes on. It is my understanding that it is the 2nd oldest bar in SF. The service is always really friendly.
author: Amy E.

description:
Good pub. Darts, tables, chairs, couches, stools, bar stools, victorian lamps, chalk boards, tv's, music. Its filled with stuff, with more room for people. 

Nice beers, though you can still get the cheap standards if you must (bud-miller etc). I like the atmosphere a lot.
author: Marz W.

description: Great places in the area to bring in food...Yumma (Mediterranean Wraps on Irving btw 8th and 9th), Pasquale's Pizza (on Irving and 7th)
author: Maggie M.

description:
Cafe Du Nord aside, this is my favorite bar in SF so far (but so far I haven't been too that many).  Why? Simple-it's everything I want in a bar.  Cozy and amiable, with couches, fireplace, and all-around great ambience.  Plus, board games! (Though it's true, you're better off bringing your own)

Seriously, once upon a time this was what bars were for: getting together and socializing.  Nowadays, people want me to go to some club where they're pounding dance music into your head so hard you can't even hear yourself think, let alone order a drink, let alone *talk* to anyone, and when I say no, they accuse me of being anti-social.  Au contraire, mon ami, I am *too* social for that sort of thing, unless you define bumping and grinding as socializing.  Ok, rant over.  But if that strikes a chord, you'll understand why I love the Little Shamrock.
author: Wes M.

description:
I love this place.  (And if you know me well, I'm not saying that because I have an Irish ex-boyfriend.  I'm not, really...Ok, maybe I am.)  It's always friendly and low key, even when it's busy.  The drinks are priced reasonably and there's a ton of hang out space.  

And the couches are especially good for making out with Irish people, if you do that type of thing in public.
author: Stefanie B.

description:
THE BEST EVER! 

...If you live in the sunest-otherwise its way the f*** out there. its the best place to go late at night when youve just got off work and no one wants to gets dressed up. you can grab a couple pitchers, a few darts, connect-four and claim the back room...

unless im there and then forget about it. the dart room is mine. sorry. lol
author: Delaney P.

description:
If you're looking for a local bar with a local feel, this is the place. It's friendly, laid back, and no one cares if you put your feet on the furniture. 

There's a dart room in the back that people constantly walk towards mistakenly thinking it's the bathroom. There is a standing rule among my friends and I: whenever someone comes back there while we are playing darts, you have to introduce yourself. It's a great way to meet new people!
author: Darcy V.

description:
Scenario: Done with Nightlife at the Cal Academy of Sciences and I get invited to have a drink.  At some point darts enter the equation...

Product: Affordable drinks and a decent selection for a small-ish place.  There are a couple dart boards in the back.

Service: The bartender was friendly and attentive.

Atmosphere: Definitely cozy, with a fireplace and a few nooks and crannies for people to hide out in.  I'd like to go here again some time and just chill with a friend.  The location right next to GG park and some good food spots (like Marnee Thai) is a definite plus.

Uniquity: Little Shamrock is a good place to hang, even if you're desperately trying not to lose at darts AGAIN to the exceptionally amiable young lady next to you.  If you don't like darts, the price and location are definitely worth a look see.
author: Robert R.

description:
Apparently I've left The Little Shamrock out of my "Inner Sunset Pub Crawl" review.  Sorry!
More than half of the time it's packed with the kind of douchebags I thought I'd left in Orange County.  
BUT when it's a mellow night and you're sitting in an old couch playing Trivial Pursuit with just the cards or taking over the darts room with your best friends, The Shamrock can feel like home.
author: Eric S.

description:
I went to Little Shamrock with my brothers to watch the 49'ers play the Giants in the playoffs.  Unfortunately the 49'ers lost but the day as a whole was great.  All do to the Little Shamrock. The atmosphere was perfect. I'm not from the area but when you enter this bar you feel at home. Clean, with an old feel and no smells. The bar tender was accommodating and knowledgeable.

 My favorite part of Little Shamrock's is the server Caitlin. She made my brothers and I feel at home, she is very pretty, and she was fast with the service. Did I already say that Caitlin was hot and nice. Anyways, thank you Little Shamrock for a great experience with the bro's.
author: Max F.

description: I don't know why I've never been to this bar, I love it! Casual atmosphere and $8 for a vodka gimlet is pricey BUT it's actually not because they give you the shaker and it fills the small martini glass at least 2 times! I love it got nice and buzzed
author: Karen T.

description: Awesome neighborhood bar. Perfect to just hang and have a drink, play some cards and other board games available. Good service through the bartender and a waitress does come around to take orders. It would be nice if they took card but it makes up with it's all around atmosphere.
author: Michael L.

description:
Went here on the fly after having dinner with a group of friends. At the time we came, it was actually not busy at all so we proceeded to the back where we ended up having the whole dartboard room to ourselves.

First off, this venue has character. Between the random photos and junk hung on the wall and the random messages written in chalk all over the wall, you end up with a whole bunch of eye candy that will make you laugh, or roll your eyes. They have a server that comes to the back room to serve drinks... fully awesome. The dart boards are actually in decent shape we had no trouble playing the game (that is until more people showed up and we had to rotate with the outside crowd, but no biggie). Add cheap alcohol prices and you are set for one drunken night!

Definitely a great place to go!
author: Diana R.

description: Feeling a bit of the Irish after a long volleyball tournament and what better way to celebrate a crushing loss then with a beer. Quaint place and they have Boddingtons in a can... at least they have it.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
I would only give this place three stars except for the fact it has a bunch of board games--most importantly, Scrabble. I've come here a few times for an after-dinner Scrabble game with friends. Word to the word-lovers: the first time I played, there were definitely more than the normal 100 tiles; the second time, there were exactly 100 tiles, but not entirely in the appropriate quantities. You're on your own for paper and a pen to keep score.

Otherwise, it's a bar. I'm not really a bar person, but it's pretty clean, lit well, and has a nice staff. Plus, when you're not formulating your next move (Scrabble or otherwise), there are four TVs to keep you entertained.
author: Katie I.

description:
oh, dear shammy.  a great place to meet up with friends after work.  it's the 2nd oldest bar in the city (the saloon is the oldest).  it's haunted.  the bartenders rock.  the drinks are inexpensive.  i wish they still let dogs in, but my stella enjoys hanging outside for a bit and saying hello to all the dogs coming and going to the park.

it's just about all i could ask for in a neighborhood pub.  mellow.  quiet (mostly).  

ask for a flyer with the history of the place.  it's actually pretty interesting.
author: cheryl f.

description:
Now that I live right around the corner from this place, I'm going to be spending a lot of time here.  

Their drinks are the cheapest in the neighborhood, and the bar tenders are great.

Perfect place to watch a Warriors game, play board games with friends, or just chill.
author: Chris Q.

description:
what's not to love? drinks - nice and stiff. entertainment - a plenty. fancy furniture - if quaint's your word, then yes.

i'm definitely planning on hanging with my Mr. Cooper (if you don't know who he is, you owe me a shot) next time around.
author: Maria B.

description:
Clearly, I've been duped.  I have spent my time and my money at the other great inner sunset bars (Mucky Duck ranks tops).  I had visited this "Little Shamrock" on one previous occasion... and found it lacking (too many people, too loud, etc etc).  Of course, the only night I had been here was the night EVERYBODY went here... the night of the DeYoung opening party.

2 Friends and I decided to check this place out last weekend, and we were knocked out of our socks.  We LOVED it!  Great friendly staff, great tables, free popcorn (not always the freshest), and the cheapest beer in the 'hood.  We had been to 2 other bars already on this Friday night, and paid the least for the 3 beers... and they even came with more smiles than the others had.

They have tables, games, good loos.  As we walked in looking for a table, I asked my friends what beer they wanted, prepared to stand at the bar and be ignored for 5 minutes because I hadn't been there every night for the past 12 years.  A "bar maid" / "waitress" / "beer getter" (what's PC for this?) overheard me asking them, and offered to get them for us.  Great service!

We'll definitely be back.
author: Bruce W.

description:
2 stars for quick-witted bartender
1 star for having board games

-2 stars for having really dirty couches
author: Krista C.

description:
Ok, ok... granted some of you might notice that this is my second attempt at reviewing this fine Inner Sunset establishment.  Other Yelpers, with active, healthy lives, however, won't notice and probably won't even remember reading this review fifteen minutes from now.  

So, why did I rewrite my review?  What new things do I have to say about the Little Shamrock that I felt wasn't adequately discussed in previous reviews?  Life.

That's right - Life.  And I'm not talking about "life" in the sense that requires intense gesticulation, arching your eyebrows, and knowingly looking directly into someone's eyes: "Dude, you know, like, LIFE and everything."

No, I'm merely talking about the less grandiose board game "Life."  The Little Shamrock has Life.  That's right.  Oh, and they have Simpson's Clue.  Chess?  You better believe it.  Fuck, they even have Backgammon tables.  

So you may think to yourself, "Hmmm, so you are giving this place 5 stars because it has a few board games?"

If you did think that, or if I could see that thought flash through your eyes for a second, I'd be all like, "No.  Dude.  No.  They have a fucking popcorn machine too."  I mean, I've never seen them actually use it to actually make popcorn, and the popcorn in it is usually a little stale, but wait until your fourth drink - you'll understand why this is huge.

So, surely I'd detract a point because there is sometimes a funky odor in there, right?  Well, ok - sure I'll detract a point for that, but it would earn that star right back because the staff is awesome and they have a little back room where you can play darts.  Even better, the darts room has its own stereo so you can blast whatever music you want in the back and not bother the diverse mixture of patrons hanging out in the front room.  

Anyways, I like the Little Shamrock a lot, and if you stop by on a good night - you probably will too.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Comfy casual bar with couches in the back, and tables and board games, a free popcorn machine, super cheap drinks, vintagey (ie. worn in with love or just plain old) furniture and great bartenders that are never cranky or rude.  

This is the kind of place you can go to alone and walk out with a bunch of new friends.  

Perfect place to hang out with friends.  Anytime.
author: Denise B.

description: This place is awesome. The interior is cozy and full of archaic touches like stained glass lamps and dark stained wood. The drinks are cheap, the staff is nice and they have a whole room just for darts. We like to order beers and whiskeys and play cards. If I ever learn to play backgammon then we'll totally take advantage of the awesome tables they have for that weird game.
author: Valerie G.

description: I didn't spend too much time in here, but by the looks of it I would say it's a nice bar. Lots of different types of seating. It's got a sort of hipster feel, but not in the usual annoying way. It's just a lot different than most of the Chinese run bars in the district. I like it!
author: Chris I.

description: For a pub this place is pretty cool. While I'm not generally a fan of this type of establishment, they do have some great old couches and other furniture to lounge in with a pint. I can't remember what the music was like but the bartender was really nice and opened a fresh bottle of wine for me when she discovered that what was open had turned. Also if you're in need if something to soak up your libations, the Mediterranean joint next door is top notch.
author: Michelle L.

description:
This place is like a big, neighborhood living room.  The couches are old and a little grimy, but you will find them to be quite comfortable and there's plenty of room to lounge about.   You can sit at the tables and play board games or you can squeeze onto a sofa right next to the fireplace.  Drinks are reasonably priced and there's a decent selection of beer on tap.  Best of all, there's a dart room in the back!  
Basically, this place is a comfortable neighborhood pub that feels homey and warm.  If you are looking for loud music or anything hip, you'll probably be disappointed.
author: Laura C.

description:
I've lived in the Inner Sunset for a few years and finally decided to see what The Little Shamrock had to offer.  Sure glad I did!

The next time I want to grab a drink in my neighborhood, this is where I'm going.  The decor rocks... lots of San Francisco's history can be found on the walls, the chairs are comfy, and it's so cool of them to offer free popcorn and board games to play.

It's definitely a "local" spot... so you can't come in here all dolled up with your girlfriends all "hootin' and hollerin'" and expect a warm welcome.  Most folks in here are chillin' with a pint of Guinness...
author: Jess R.

description:
I really, really like the Little Shamrock. My girlfriend and I went there on our first date and had a blast. It got off to a little bit of a rocky start when I went up to the bar to buy the first round and saw the $4 in my wallet wasn't enough to pay for drinks and they don't accept cards. My face turned bright red but luckily she was a good sport about it and covered me, I probably still owe her a couple of bucks for the drinks. 

We played scrabble and I let her win, just like I've let her win every game since. We've been back there a few more times to play board games and darts and have always had a good time. Definitely a fun place to hang out.
author: Chris T.

description: The little shamrock is a lot of fun the drinks our very strong and the people our friendly, my girlfriend and I went there last week and we had a good time.
author: Virginia V.

description:
My idea of the perfect bar to have a drink alone. Not that I drink alone much, but for the 2-5 days I week that might do so, this is where I'd wanna do it. It's never too loud, so drowning my sorrows seems more pleasantly miserable. And it's never too terribly busy, so I don't have to feel bad for putting down a dozen or so drinks alone and then stumbling back to my house two blocks away at 4 pm. It's Irish, but lacks the obnoxious folks and the constant barrage of U2, traditional drinking songs and Riverdance music. 

Comfy. Cozy. Boozy.
author: Brandon B.

description:
I love the location of the bar, since I'm a fan of a few neighbors- Canvas, Le Video, Kiki- and I really like the nearby Starbucks.  A group of four of us settled on a couch and a couple of chairs towards the back of the bar near the hearth.  It was very warm and cozy.  Then we proceeded to play a couple of games we brought with us.  We had a ton of fun.  I got over the whole multiple use popcorn basket aversion by lining them with a napkin...though that probably didn't help much overall.  The bartender was slower than molasses going up a tree in winter, but the drinks were priced reasonably. 
What else?....the furniture did smell a little ripe and one of the bathrooms was bizarre- it's just a long, narrow corridor with a sink at one end and the toilet at the other.  I felt like I was in a prison.  They need to stop by the bathroom at Mangosteen for inspiration.
author: CAKE E.

description:
This place makes a great irish coffee. think a big ass shot of jameson with a hint of coffee. if you like them strong, check out the ones here.

i also like this place because they have backgammon built into the tables.
author: Bernie L.

description:
1/2 star because its close to my apt. 
1/2 star because they have popcorn (but you have to fight the mouse to get some) 
1 star because they have games

no stars because its so bright that i seriously need my sunglasses at night. i guess its ok if you want to play games, but they could still turn it down a notch from blindness. some chairs are comfy enough, but one couch is ass-breaking stiff.

its is 345 years old or something....and it smells like it too!
author: K. T.

description:
I have been meaning to visit this place for ages, after hearing that they make one of the best bloody marys in the city. Sure enough, they were quite tasty. What I hadn't heard about was the variety of games they have just waiting to be played (if you have the patience to sort out the playing cards).

The dart room is cool, but standing only 5'3", I felt the boards were hung really, really high. Like 8" above my eyeline. Didn't keep me from playing though.
author: Cat S.

description: I love this bar. I also love Irish beers. They have quite a few of them. It is always packed, bartenders are friendly, price is alright (cash only). Boardgames for those who want to play boardgames in a bar. Cool stuff on the walls. Variety of different seating options !!
author: Deepak K.

description: Everything has been said. My highlights are the super cheap drinks, great DART ROOM in back and all the games everywhere. The people that rate this place two stars are idiots. 'Nuff said.
author: Christopher N.

description:
Been going to the Shamy for years this is a proper pub hassle free with stained glass lamps that the owner made years ago. 
Saw someone wrote that it's messy ha ha, well, if you want some high end lounge go to the matrix and hang out with the trustafarians in the marina. The shamy is a cool locals spot where you can have a fun night and not get hassled.
author: Dave G.

description:
This is one of my favorite neighborhood bars. Once around the holidays, I walked into the Little Shamrock and all these friendly looking people started handing me cookies and candy and there was this crazy guy playing the piano and everyone was singing Christmas carols. That's the kind of place it is. 
I love the art work, there are lots of cool lamps and beatiful stained glass. I really dig that they have board games, as board games provide a fun activity when you are socially awkward, like me. Although the games are a little run down; I wouldn't expect Clue, for example, to have all the murder suspects, weapons, and rooms. But I have played a mean game of boggle here. This place is quieter than most bars, which I like because you can actually hear it when someone says something to you. And props to the popcorn.
author: Kathleen B.

description: rustic and wooden saloon...appearance casual and atmosphere "dive"...but, wouldn't classify as "dive"... $five guinness gulp...not cheap...and, no shamrock in foam...weekend early evening...seemingly locals and dinner wait bar....sit, order and wait evening...games around for play...
author: Hen A.

description:
This is my local, even though I've never lived "local" to it. Great atmosphere, reasonable prices, lots of regulars, and free popcorn. What else can you ask for? 

The Shammy is a great pub and one of the best in The City.
author: Ryan S.

description: Great bar!  Made me feel right at home, even though we were just visiting.  We met the staff and other patrons and thought everyone was friendly.  Great place to tell a tall tale, or even a short one.  They have board games, darts and great atmosphere.  I was told it's the longest running bar in SF.
author: Carmen S.

description:
A nice bar where even a nerd like me can sit and and feel comfortable.
Relaxed, unpretentious, neighborhood pub.  Aside fro the name, they really don't overplay the Irish theme.  Its just a cool place to chill out, , watch a game or play a board game.  I wish they had a trivia night.
author: W M.

description:
When I moved to San Francisco, this was one of the first bars I went to. When I left San Francisco, this was one of the last bars I went to. I recall the first time, it was pouring. It was 2000, and to get there we had to strut from STATE on the 19th ave bus to Lincoln, and hiked over with our umbrellas. Did I say it was pouring that night? Wow, trenchcoat whether. When we walked in, I remember thinking how cool the bar looked, it's OLD. In fact, it's the 2nd oldest bar in San Francisco! Another thing I noticed, quickly, was that it gets so crowded! The last time I went to Little Shamrock, nothing changed. It looks the same as the first day I stepped foot, only this time the weather was better....it was just a slight drizzle :)

During weekdays, You'll often find athletes having post-game drinks. It's where coed leagues like to meet up after playing their games. Speaking of games, there are various behind the bar that you can ask for, should the occasion suit you. Order beer by the pitcher, or not. They got Magner's by the bottle, so you can't miss there.
author: M S.

description: Cheap beer, friendly staff, plenty of seating, this place is rad! Everything is a little dirty, but the place is just totally chill. Really an awesome bar to go and just hang out with some friends and have some beer - I feel like I'm kicking back in my living room when I'm here.
author: Ben Y.

description:
This long low ceiling bar just oozes character, I think its the second oldest bar in San Francisco, and I believe the bathrooms are the oldest, or at least they smell that old.
Having said that, its a cool neighborhood bar, not really Irish, more American, Good quiz night, good selection of beers. There is one character who sits at the bar most of the day surrounded by TV remote controls, he even has his own barstool, on which you dare not sit , only room for one asshole there, the word loser was invented for this guy.
But go have a beer here, you'll like the atmosphere, the beer and bartenders, and most of the patrons.
author: Paula M.

description: The Little Shamrock (or "the shammy" as we refer to it these days) is still my favorite bar in SF. And I recently found out.... drumroll please... it's the 2nd OLDEST BAR IN SAN FRANCISCO! I can't believe I never knew that.  It's literally a part of San Francisco history. And they serve great drinks, have really friendly bartenders, and the most comfortable, welcoming atmosphere. Gotta love it.
author: Brandi C.

description: This place makes me feel unclean but in a mildly good way. It's got old furniture, old popcorn, old bathrooms, and sometimes I ponder what I will be like when I get old while in here. This thought usually occurs when I am playing one of their old board games with missing pieces. Then I figure if I become an old drunk one day and don't like it I can stand in front of the old dart board (in the very, very, very distant future of course) and get taken out by one of their old patrons. Too bad the drinks aren't priced in alignment with a bygone era, but they are reasonable by modern day standards.  This is a decent place, I suppose, if you want to do some good old fashioned drinking.
author: Drue C.

description: This is a fun little place with an amazing jovial atmosphere.  It's a little in the middle  of nowhere for us city dwellers, but if you ever find yourself out in the area, definitely stop off for a pint or two.
author: Mason G.

description: OK - i haven't made it back to the 'Rock since my last review but it's been eating at me that I gave such a great place one star...I will assume they have the tap situation under control and re-instate the proper 5 star status....
author: Brian H.

description: I really love this kind of neighborhood bar. Really good character. A great way to spend an afternoon or evening. My only complaints are that they only take cash and they don't have Smithwick on tap.
author: William C.

description: Absolutely love this bar. Good beer on tap. Very cozy and comfortable. A group of us played Trivial Pursuit, sipped brews, relaxed in comfy chairs. Perfect way to spend a night!
author: Sonya D.

description: A nice comfy bar with couches, lots of seats and games. i'm afraid this place loses a star for guiness that was 1 or 2 degrees too warm, it's not true that the brits like their beer warm and especially not guiness, criminal. Big plus for this bar was the games, couple of backgammon boards set into a couple of the tables and a stack of board games piled in the back. Don't count on all the pieces being there but there should be enough to cobble together a game. Nice selection of beers on tap, PBR, Anchor Steam, pilsner urquell, harp, and a pretty good local IPA.
author: Karl L.

description: This spot RULES! Totally the best dive bar in my hood, it's like being in a hippie coffee shop, but with beer! Board games to pass the time, bartenders always are fast and spot on with your order, but my fave thing in the place has to be the old clock on the wall, that stopped during the great quake. Total slice of San Francisco history. Just kick back on one of those couches with a beer, and relax!
author: Robbie G.

description:
nice, casual, fun atmosphere.
and good beers.
place kinda crowded most of the time, especially friday night.
author: JX S.

description: "Sometime you wanna go where everybody knows your name...".  ok, cheezy, I know, but that's how I feel about the Sham.  This is where my boyfriend took me out on our first date, and that's how I knew he was a keeper.  This is probably one of the best, coziest, and most fun bars in the city. There's board games, gross popcorn that I can never stay away from, pool, darts, a fireplace, comfy ass chairs, and cool bar tenders. It's just a real laid back no frills no bs place.    Also, they let me watch the Sox games whenever they're on, so major brownie points for that.  So yeah, if you ever see a bunch of dogs tied up out front, that means we're there being rowdy and having fun- come on in and join!!
author: Liz S.

description: I haven't reviewed Lil' Shamrock yet??? I've only been going here 20 years, I mean, why would i review it? This place is classic. Good beer choice, friendly help and customers, clean bathrooms, a fire, a darts room, lots of seating (and types thereof) and very interesting and historic decor. It also happens to be the second oldest bar in S.F. with a clock on the wall that stopped during a certain 1906 event. Whether you live here or are visiting, you just have to stop in. You can bring Milano's pizza in too. (maybe others too, but that seems to be the norm)
author: Rich M.

description:
last night was the worst experience i've ever had at the sham and i'm still giving it five stars.
this is why:
1) it's the best.
2 ) drew
3) the worlds longest bathroom
4) the lamps
5) the games
6) the music
7) the festivity
8) the locals

there are two kinds of people here. people who go to the sham and people that live at the sham.  i would fall into that latter category. and in no way is that depressing.
author: marin m.

description: Love their irish coffees and baileys and coffee ;) friendly staff and we can play backgammon which is fun! Love this place cuz it's not packed all the time so you don't fight to get drinks or anything crazy! Perfect for a rainy night if you wanna cozy up to the fireplace there too! We love going to the Little Shamrock, love irish pubs ;)
author: Jennifer T.

description: The Little Shamrock is tits. Where else can you get inexpensive Irish pub drinks with popcorn, and a full lesson on backgammon and darts?  Drew, the bartender on Friday and Saturday nights is a total sweetheart, while Lara the cocktail waitress is sure to delight.  This place has all the charm of a late 19th century establishment, without the fear of being shanghai'ed. You must try the signature drink, "Taymore Don't" or the ever popular "Irish Car Bomb."  A great place for friends, games, and pints. Must try!!!!
author: Zach F.

description: Its dingy and it sometimes smells a little like wet cat.  They serve popcorn in bowls that haven't been cleaned since 1906.  So if you're germaphobic, obsessive-compulsive, or sensitive to smell, mold, or loud music, this may not be your fave.  But the alcohol is reasonably-priced and they have Connect Four.  Connect Four!  Is there another bar in the city that has this game?  I've never had a bad time there.
author: Richard T.

description: There are no complete sets of board games on the stack in the back.  Best to bring your own.  I like to bring some non-typical boardgame or one that requires intricate assembly like Mousetrap or RockemSockem Robots just to be obnoxious.  Have you ever played Perfection?  The one where you have 60 seconds to put a million peg shapes in their corresponding slots before it POPS and you have a mess to clean up?  This would also be a great game to play here.  All the beer and aggravated nerves and having to pick up a million pieces on the stained, popcorn littered floor and the amalgam of badly upholstered parlor furniture and discarded waiting room chairs = good times had by all.
author: Marjorie B.

description: I had a great time here for an organized game night. There was plenty of seating for people to group around a game board. The drinks are very affordable and the overall vibe of the place was chill and relaxed. Definitely recommend this pub to hang out with friends. This is the kind of place you could even bring your parents.
author: Allisoto P.

description: Little Shamrock has many amenities. There are plenty of tables and comfy chairs, a dartboard, a fireplace, popcorn, cheap well drinks, and Boont Oatmeal Stout on tap. But what's really great about this bar is that it has a good cross-section of patrons. There are middle-aged groups of friends, med students, house painters, a fashionista or two, and MGD-drinking dinosaurs with flipped-up collars on their polo shirts. All in relative harmony, like those videos you see of the African savanna when there's been plenty of rain. The heart of this kaleidoscope of patrons, however, are the regulars: Old men with no teeth who come in every day of their lives and chat with the (totally stoned) bartender. Their teeth are like the board games here: missing a few pieces, but basically functional. And increasingly amusing the more you drink.
author: Ben P.

description: This ain't a bar for cocktails.  Don't even try.  The bartender -- it doesn't matter what bartender -- will have to open a book and follow directions to mix it for you.  Just order a beer/cider, grab a bowl of popcorn, and play a game of backgammon.  Don't know how to play?  Sit at the table and look confused for a minute and some drunk old guy will come tell you how.  It's that easy.
author: Nora B.

description: One of the oldest bars in San Francisco. Peep the grandfather clock on the wall that has the same time on it since it stopped in the 1906 earthquake. There is no better place to enjoy a good Irish whiskey whilst munching on popcorn and keeping your wits about you with a nice friendly game of backgammon. Nice.
author: Matthew R.

description: I would have given this place 3 stars but they had Speakeasy Prohibition so I had to add a star.  Great relaxed atmosphere, really eclectic group of peeps here.  Everyone was friendly and seemed to know one another.  There was a very cozy feel about the place and the fire place was a nice surprise since it was quite windy and cold out.  I immediately warmed my bum and got toasty enough to take my sweater off.   The bar tender was a bit slow and not as receptive to my needs as I would have liked.  The bathroom was very alice  and wonderland....a sink at one end and 15 feet later....the toilet.  Check out the pic.
author: Juliana M.

description: This is my new bar, and if I had it my way, it'd be my place of business and possibly residence as well.  It's comfy, friendly, boozy, and some other positive adjectives.  They've been around since before the 1906 earthquake, according to the sign outside.  I'm not sure what else you'd want in a bar.
author: Phil K.

description: Okay so as far as sunset bars goes this used to be my favorite place. Darts in the back, comfy seating, popcorn, cheap beer, seemingly good people, they have actual board games to play if you feel so inclined but the last few times I have been in here the bartender has had a shiteous attitude that I am starting to resent him for. Bartenders work for their money, I know I've been one, but dude seriously I come to this place in a good mood and leave wanting to kick your ass. alright, I've said too much.
author: courtney b.

description: These guys do nothing less than make you happy. The atmosphere is fantastic, and the boys & girls behind the bar know what they're doing. An Irish coffee in the afternoon?  No problem. A couple shots for your fiends, followed with the perfect chaser and a great story? Sold. This place is for you. And your friends.
author: Andrew K.

description: OK, my Friend got married and I went up to San Francisco...This bar was on our way and it claimed to be open 112 years and the prices show it...Walked in felt more British then Irish (Which Speaks volumes)...Beer was high for a pint and not much dark beer on the list just Guinness and that's it. I made the mistake and ordered one. Upon my first sip I felt a bitter fruit taste that I Swear upon my life tasted like Durian, that Crazy Asian fruit.  I looked down the bar were 7 or 8 people where drinking it fine...So I thought it was a new Hybrid beer I haven't Tired, so i called the waiter over and asked what the hell it is, she told me it was normal Guinness...I was speechless all i could say was try it. She did and told me that's how Guinness tastes... I asked for a manger because I couldn't drink the sinful filth...When he drink it he spit it out and said it was spoiled...All he could do was give my friend and I half off another drink...I upon my Roman Catholic Irish Faith, say all this to be true...and its time to close her down. Its slap in the face to every Irish blooded mate that whats through that door. Never again....
author: Joseph P.

description: Seriously....SO CHEAP! PBR drafts for $2, liquor drinks for 5ish. Nice place to hang out and have a few cheap drinks.
author: Beth T.

description: Great full bar with good beers and liquor selection.  I didn't see their wine selection, but this isn't really the place for wine I think.  I could be wrong though.  They allow you to bring food in and there are tons of places nearby, so the no kitchen thing isn't a big deal.  It's comfy inside with couches and board games.  Bartender was nice on Saturday afternoon.
author: Emma L.

description: Came on a Sunday night and it was pretty quiet. The bartender was really friendly. Lots of comfortable space to hang out and drink and just chill with friends. Free popcorn.
author: G G.

description: They don't serve food, but they let us bring in whatever we wanted, awesome! We brought in some really tasty Mediterranean food from next door and enjoyed eating it in the cute pub. Very comfy chairs and several TVs above the bar.
author: Cassandra T.

description: On any given night you'll find a few locals, a few students and a large number of Academy staff knockin 'em back.  One of my favorite places to go for a quick drink post-work. The complimentary popcorn always hits the spot, and sometimes this couple brings in their super cool dachschund.
author: Lisa R.

description: Another cozy, non-descript Inner Sunset bar that's perfect for a relaxing night out. Just chill, play some backgammon, sip your beer and ponder how life is so good...
author: Michael E.

description: This is probably the best bar in the Inner Sunset...although it doesn't have very much strong competition.  I like the popcorn, board games, decent prices and cozy atmosphere-- great for a cold and foggy day.  As others have said, the cocktails aren't very good, and the quality of service really varies from day to day.  But it's still a good place to meet people on a slow night.
author: Lego S.

description: Shammy Sham, oh so dependable.  It's like you're favorite sweater--grey, worn out and scuzzied, but you still love it anyway.  There's free popcorn and table service--you gotta love that.  Loads of board games, too.  I monopolize the Connect 4 game when I'm there.  Funny how no one fights me for it.
author: M A N I K.

description: This place is awesome! The oatmeal stout is superb, the atmosphere and people were really friendly. $5 for a stout is a good price, coming from LA where beer is $7-10. Anyway, they have a darts section, where its really comfortable and fun. I really enjoyed this place, I will return again when i'm in the city again.
author: Antonio Z.

description: Sit in the back - the couches are comfy, and it's a little less crowded/distracting. The Connect 4, Battleship, and OLD trivia pursuit games will put a smile on your face... and so will the friendly staff. Popcorn is free, but it's pretty dry so it's not really worth the effort. Good place to bring some friends and kick back on a Friday night.
author: Anika K.

description: Well, I definitely still suck at chess and can see why chewed me out for making her buy me a marble chess set. Oh yeah, this is supposed to be a bar review. This place is pretty solid. If wanted to get shitfaced with my closest friends and nobody else, I'd hang here and play scrabble, boggle(if anybody knows how, let me know), or chess. Anywas, the drinks are cheap, nice couches, etc,etc.
author: Srinivas R.

description: This is a great little bar on Lincoln that is very hospitable to board gamers alike. They have their own board games as well as a backgammon table for you to dabble with, and welcome you to bring your own as well. The owner is very hospitable. One amazing thing I noticed is they have Bottington's on tap! This is probably the only place I've ever seen with this creamy beer on tap. They also serve Corona's with lime for only 3 dollars on Sundays! What a deal and also a great place to just hang out with friends.
author: Dave Y.

description: What happens when you cross a worn victorian bar with a collection of  crazy stained glass? Lil shamrock. one of the oldest bars in the city, its definately one of my fav' haunts. the beers are great, the popcorn is always tasty, and hey, who knew playing clue drunk without cards could be so fun?
author: Tim V.

description: i like this place alot. went for the first time yesterday... it was cozy, warm, a good amount of beers on tap. a good place to take shelter from the wind and fog that took over the inner sunset. id go back for sure.
author: nate c.

description:
best dive bar in the sunset. friendly people. and lots of games, with dartboards in the back.  free popcorn. 
recommended drink: carbomb.
author: Roy N.

description: Have been here twice and I like the place.  I would give it one more star if not for the apathetic bartendress serving last night.  I say apathetic because we had to wait a bit before we could order our drinks because she had to count quarters in the register.  But it seemed like one of those tasks where she was trying to do it to stall because she didn't like the looks of me and my friend?  Or maybe multitasking is a bitch.  I didn't take it too personally, she looked like she might have been pregnant and been on her feet all day so I'd be cranky too, but you know you can't ask those questions.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Fun place! Comfy chairs, Guiness on tap, and fresh free popcorn (just ask!). They've been really accommodating whenever a slew of us come visit from the Academy of Sciences. Good location, too!
author: dj z.

description: Love this place, only wish I lived in this neighborhood so's I could walk home. I adore the little bartender man with the dark curly hair. I only wish he wouldn't force us out right at two:( I just wont go here on the weekends, it gets a little crowd, with not my crowd. I prefer the folk during the week.
author: Lindsey H.

description: I went here a while ago with a friend to play a game of chess. I love the atmosphere and they had lots of games there to play. I brought my own chess board which I am thinking of donating to them. This is a great place to just hang out with friends. I actually liked the stale popcorn, it went well with the beer.
author: E P.

description: Of all the Irish bars and pubs in the sunset/richmond, this one is probably the most legit.  Long history, board games, friendly atmosphere, cool neighborhood, what more would you expect from a 100+ year old Irish dive?
author: Alex K.

description: Sunday afternoons, ah sunday afternoons. My favorite time of the week. After losing at multiple games of handball in the park, I'm ready for a beer and redemption on the dart board. Little Shamrock is part of my Sunday ritual and they have never dissapointed me. Beer is cold. Popcorn is good. Backgammon is hard. Darts are dangerous when you're drinking, but all are oh so fun! Thank you Little Shamrock for your hand in making the ONLY day off I have, such a pleasant one.
author: Nuvia C.

description: A good, solid bar. If you get there early you can secure really comfortable seating in plush armchairs and sofas. Don't come here expecting space on a beautiful weekend, though. This place is *packed* with people. Overall nothing great to say, but nothing wrong with it, either.  Another Irish bar, if that.
author: David Z.

description: Great little bar. They have backgammon tables set up. What else could you ask for? Couches, real chairs, tables, wall knick knacks. Even old men drinking beer on a Tuesday watching the game. I love it.
author: James C.

description: The little shamrock is one of those bars that can become your favorite hang out almost as soon as you walk in the door.  It is perhaps the best rainy day bar in the city.  The atmosphere is cozy, they have ample board games (and tables to play them on), and they even show rugby games on the tv.  It's also a lot of fun to play darts in the back room.  The regulars all seem friendly, as does the staff.  The booze is pretty cheap.  What else...oh and the bar has a very authentic/historic feel to it (another reviewer already mentioned the grandfather clock that stopped ticking in 1906, right after the great earthquake).  So, the little shamrock is a great place to enjoy a few with some good friends, and think about earthquakes.
author: Mr. G.

description: Chess and backgammon on the tables, lots of comfy couches and charis in the back, cheap pitchers, and all the freshly popped popcorn you can eat make this place a great bar.  I'd be happy to come back to this place anytime.
author: matthew w.

description: Nice relaxing Irish bar in the Sunset district.  I enjoyed my New Castle and doing trivia with old Trivia Pursuit cards.  Only complaint is it's slightly dirty and run down but I guess that's what gives it its character...
author: Scott L.

description: favorite pub.  I'm so glad I can walk there, and stumble home.
author: Peter H.

description: Yeah, that's right.  One Friday night, instead of the usual go out, get drunk, dance, and stumble home routine; some of us decided to go out, get drunk, play games, and stumble home.  A very good time was had by all in this little bar far far away from where i live.  We all had headaches by the end of the night from games like set, apples to apples, scattergories, taboo, scrabble...  The waitress was a doll for dealing with a huge group of us taking over the back half ( it was only her 2nd day on the job) and the other patrons didn't get too pissed off there once we got there even though going to the bathroom became an obstacle course.  I drank Fat tire all night and it was cold, delicious, and well priced.  Since we were playing games all night, nobody got too drunk, and I believe I remember everybody's names (bonus).  Plus, the bar had a couple of t.v.s showing sports (soccer!!!)   So 5 stars for games, t.v.s, nice waitress, good people, and good memories.
author: John B.

description: a charming little neighborhood bar.  i can't believe it took my roommate and me an entire year to finally make it down here.  it's really cozy inside, complete with a fireplace, backgammon tables, and an assortment of boardgames.  everyone inside looks like a regular.  the roomie and i enjoyed a solid game of chess (yes, i finally found someone who sucks as much as i do, so we could have a worthwhile game!).  i think we'll be coming back pretty regularly from now on...
author: Roshni R.

description: The beers were cheap, but the bartender was rude. And there was a mouse. And the bathrooms were gross (worse than most dive bars.)
author: Caitlin B.

description: highly recommend this bar. quaint little place with a good selection of beers on tap. bartenders and servers are always real cool and you cant beat their board game selection. when was the last time you played battleship? break the ice? i haven't played that damn game since second grade but i played it here. you really cant go wrong at the little shamrock.
author: Mike K.

description: Great laid back bar with a nice bartender...plus popcorn - gotta love popcorn.  Darts in the way back with an old radio that you can control makes it feel like you're in your own rec room - if your rec room had old couches and random (and obscene) chalk messages all over the walls.  There was an old Frogger video game that sadly did not work.  I wish they had more of a selection of beer on tap but they have a pretty good variety.
author: Sofia S.

description:
shamrock is the reason i've never paid the deYoung a sober visit.

thank you, shamrock.
author: Kerry N.

description: I stumbled upon this bar one night and am glad I did! Very laid back, friendly bartender, good seating, games (board games), and close to home. It is everything you can expect from a small Irish pub, and I like it :)
author: Annie L.

description: I love this place!  It's a tiny corner dive bar with lots of little games (i.e. darts, etc...) and the drinks are cheap.  There is tons of seating a free popcorn.  This is a great place to head to with a group of friends for a drink.
author: L M K M.

description: i've been here several times and still i'm on the fence between 2 and 3 stars.  the drinks are cheap and there are darts in the back which is a good start.  i guess i'm never really comfortable in the space, which is a bit hard to describe.  the layout of the place is pretty awkward: the dart boards are crammed in a corner in the back; the bathroom is  pain in the ass to get to and long, narrow and creepy.  it's pretty dirty, but that wasn't really my issue.  anyway, try it on if you're in the area.
author: Jo G.
